The candidates; or The humours of a Virginia election. A comedy, in three acts -- The patriots. A comedy, in five acts -- the first book of Ovid's Metamorphoses, translated -- Miscellaneous poems. Consisting of The ram: a comic poem. Letters from the Devil to his son. Answer to the winter-piece. Colin and Celia: a pastoral poem. A dream. And A patriotic song.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A COLLECTION OF PLAYS AND POEMS, BY THE LATE COL. ROBERT MUNFORD, OF MECKLENBURG COUNTY, IN THE STATE OF VIRGINIA. NOW FIRST PUBLISHED TOGETHER.
PETERSBURG: PRINTED BY WILLIAM PRENTIS. M.DCC.XCVIII.

list.item: II. The Candidates, a Comedy in three acts page 9
III. The Patriots, in five acts page 53
IV. A tranſlation of the firſt Book of Ovid's Metamorphoſes in Engliſh verſe page 133
V. The Ram, a humorous poem, written about the time when the ladies wore very high headdreſſes, being a true ſtory page 165
VI. Firſt letter from the Devil to his ſon page 194
VII. Second letter from the ſame to the ſame page 196
VIII. Anſwer to the foregoing page 197
IX. A poem in anſwer to one, entitled, "The Winter piece page 199
X. Colin and Celia; a paſtoral poem page 204

div.head: PREFACE.
div.p: THE following pages are given to the world by a ſon, whoſe filial affection may perhaps have induced him to entertain too high an opinion of the merit of his father's productions; but who candidly owns, his motives to the publication were, a conviction that the work is calculated to afford conſiderable amuſement and inſtruction, and a warm deſire to reſcue the memory of a father from oblivion.

Though to all they may not appear in the light in which they do to me, as precious memorials of that wit and poetical genius which once animated the breaſt of him who is now forever laid in the ſilent tomb, and who once was the delight of his friends and family; yet many, I hope, when they read this work, will remember a departed friend, and mourn the loſs of the man while they enjoy the humour of the poet. All I truſt will here find abundant ſubjects of merriment and diverſion.

The author appears to have thoroughly underſtood the true points of ridicule in human characters, and to have drawn them with great accuracy and variety in his comedies. The piece entitled, The Candidates, is intended to laugh to ſcorn the practice of corruption, and falſehood; of which too many are guilty in electioneering; to teach our countrymen to deſpiſe the arts of thoſe who meanly attempt to influence their votes by any thing but merit.—The play of the Patriots is a picture of real and pretended patriots; by which the reader may perceive the difference between them, may learn to honour and reward the true, and to treat the falſe with infamy and contempt. If any conſtruction ſhould be put upon it as a ſatire on the conduct of America in the late revolution, the whole tenour of the author's political conduct will exempt him from the imputation of ſuch an intention. He entered warmly into the principles of the friends of America, he • oldly fought in her defence, and proved his attachment to her cauſe not by words only, but by deeds. The play itſelf alſo ſpeaks a different language; and evidently proves it was written in ridicule of political hypocrites, and not of the true friends of their country.

With reſpect to the other poems, I believe the tranſlation of Ovid will be found to be very correct
and highly poetical. The author intended, if he had lived, to tranſlate the whole work, but death put an end to his deſign. The ſmaller poems I ſubmit to the reader, without ſaying any thing of their merit, as I wiſh not to foreſtall a pleaſure, or to raiſe too great expectations.
With theſe ſhort obſervations, gentle reader, I bid thee adieu; with a ſincere wiſh that the work before thee may afford thee rational amuſement.
THE CANDIDATES; OR, THE HUMOURS OF A VIRGINIA ELECTION. A COMEDY, IN THREE ACTS.

list.head: Candidates for the office of delegates to the general aſſembly.

list.item: Mr. Worthy, formerly a delegate, but now declines.
Jack, a tool to Mr. Strutabout.
Ned, the ſame to Mr. Smallhopes.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: LADIES and gentlemen, to-night you'll ſee
A bard delighting in ſatiric glee;
In merry ſcenes his biting tale unfold,
And high to Folly's eye the mirror hold:
Here eager candidates ſhall call for votes,
And bawling voters louder ſtretch their throats:
Here may you view, in groups diverting, join'd
The poor and wealthy rabble of mankind;
All who deſerve the laſh, the laſh will find.
Here characters, whoſe names are now unknown,
Shall ſhine again, as in their ſpheres they ſhone;
While ſome may make malicious explanation,
And know them all ſtill living in the nation.
If any preſent, ſay, fie, ſhameleſs bard!
Haſt thou for decency no more regard
Than at thy betters, thus to make a ſtand,
And boldly point out meanneſs, contraband,
Depreciating the wiſdom of the land?
Tho' ſuch, the wond'rous ſympathy of wits,
That every fool will wear the cap that fits,
I boldly anſwer, how could he mean you,
Who, when he wrote, about you nothing knew?
The ſtate of things was ſuch, in former times,
'Ere wicked kings were puniſh'd for their crimes▪
Then ſtrove the candidates to gain their ſeats
Moſt heartily, with drinking bouts, and treats;
The meaneſt vices all the people ſtain'd,
And drunkenneſs, and monarchy both reign'd,
With ſuch ſtrong cauſe his anger to engage,
How could our Bard reſtrain ſatiric rage?
But, God forbid, its edge ſhou'd now apply,
Or on our race-field, when you caſt an eye
You there a home-election—ſhould eſpy.
Science and virtue, now are wider ſpread,
And crown with dignity, fair Freedom's head.
We only pray this ſatire ne'er be juſt,
Save when apply'd to other times, and truſt
Its keenneſs only, a rememb'rancer,
And guard from future evils, may appear.
If, after this, objections ſhould remain,
The mot • ve's envy, conſciouſneſs diſdain,
Or any thing, except the poet's want
Of ſenſe, which no true publiſher will grant.
Yet virtue i • not in our ſtory loſt,
E'en then, Virginians could much virtue boaſt.
With plaudits, therefore, and free laughter own
Virginia's firſt and only comic ſon;
Ah! could the bard, rejoicing, raiſe his head
To hear his praiſe!—Alas! the bard is dead.

div.head: SCENE I. Mr. Wou'dbe's houſe.
div.stage: Enter Wou'dbe with a news-paper in his hand.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I AM very ſorry our good old governor Botetourt has left us. He well deſerved our friendſhip, when alive, and that we ſhould for years to come, with gratitude, remember his mild and affable deportment. Well, our little world will ſoon be up, and very buſy towards our next election. Muſt I again be ſubject to the humours of a fickle croud? Muſt I again reſign my reaſon, and be nought but what each voter pleaſes? Muſt I cajole, fawn, and wheedle, for a place that brings ſo little profit?

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: Sir John Toddy is below, and if your honour is at leiſure, would beg to ſpeak to you.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: My compliments to Sir John, and tell him, I ſhall be glad of his company. So—Sir John, ſome time ago, heard me ſay I was willing to reſign my ſeat in the houſe to an abler perſon, and he comes modeſtly to accept of it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Mr. Wou'dbe, your moſt obedient ſervant, ſir; I am proud to find you well. I hope you are in good health, ſir?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Very well, I am obliged to you, Sir John. Why, Sir John, you ſurely are practiſing the grimace and compliments you intend to make uſe of among the freeholders in the next election, and have introduced yourſelf to me with the ſelf-ſame common-place expreſſions that we candidates adopt when we intend to wheedle a fellow out of his vote—I hope you have no ſcheme upon me, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No, ſir, upon my honour, ſir, it was punctually to know how your lady and family did, ſir, 'pon honour, ſir, it was.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: You had better be more ſparing of your honour at preſent, Sir John; for, if you are a candidate, whenever you make promiſes to the people that you can't comply with, you muſt ſay upon honour, otherwiſe they won't believe you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Upon honour, ſir, I have no thought to ſet up for a candidate, unleſs you ſay the word.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Such condeſcenſion from you, Sir John, I have no reaſon to expect: you have my hearty conſent to do as you pleaſe, and if the people chooſe you their Repreſentative, I muſt accept of you as a colleague.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: As a colleague, Mr. Wou'dbe! I was thinking you did not intend to ſtand a poll, and my buſineſs, ſir, was to get the favour of you to ſpeak a good word for me among the people.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I hope you have no occaſion for a trumpeter, Sir John? If you have, I'll ſpeak a good word to you, and adviſe you to decline.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
Why, Mr. Wou'dbe, after you declin'd, I thought I was the next fitteneſt man in the county,
and Mr. Wou'dbe, if you would be ungenerous, tho' you are a laughing man, you would tell me ſo.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: It would be ungenerous indeed, Sir John, to tell you what the people could never be induced to believe. But I'll be ingenuous enough to tell you, Sir John, if you expect any aſſiſtance from me, you'll be diſappointed, for I can't think you the fitteneſt man I know.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, who do you know beſides? Perhaps I may be thought as fit as your honour. But, ſir, if you are for that, the hardeſt fend off: damn me, if I care a farthing for you; and ſo, your ſervant, ſir. Exit Sir John.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: So, I have got the old knight, and his friend Guzzle, I ſuppoſe, againſt me, by ſpeaking ſo freely; but their intereſt, I believe, has not weight enough among the people, for me to loſe any thing, by making them my enemies. Indeed, the being intimate with ſuch a fool as Sir John, might tend more to my diſcredit with them, for the people of Virginia have too much ſenſe not to perceive how weak the head muſt be that is always filled with liquor. Ralpho!—

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: Sir, what does your honour deſire?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I'm going into my library, and if any gentleman calls, you may introduce him to me there.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: Yes, ſir. But, maſter, as election-times are coming, I wiſh you would remember a poor ſervant, a little.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p:
Why, the laſt ſuit of clothes your honour gave me is quite worn out. Look here,
(ſh • wing
his elbows)
the inſigns, (as I have heard your honour ſay, in one of your fine ſpeeches) the inſigns of faithful ſervice. Now, methinks, as they that ſet up for bur •• ſſes, cut a daſh, and have rare ſport, why migh • not their ſervants have a little decreation?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I underſtand you, Ralpho, you wiſh to amuſe yourſelf, and make a figure among the girls this Election, and ſince ſuch a deſire is natural to the young, and innocent if not carried to exceſs, I am willing to ſatisfy you; you may therefore, have the ſuit I pulled off yeſterday, and accept this preſent as an evidence that I am pleaſed with your diligence and fidelity, and am ever ready to reward it.

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: God bleſs your honour! what a good maſter! who would not do every thing to give ſuch a one pleaſure? But, e'gad, it's time to think of my new clothes: I'll go and try them on. Gadſo! this figure of mine is not reconſiderable in its delurements, and when I'm dreſſed out like a gentleman, the girls, I'm a thinking, will find me deſiſtible. Exit.

div.head: SCENE II. A porch of a tavern: a Court-houſe on one ſide, and an high road behind.
div.stage: Captain Paunch, Ned, and ſeveral freeholders diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, I ſuppoſe we are all going to the barbecue together.
Indeed, ſir, I can aſſure you, I have no ſuch inten • ion.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Not go to your friend Wou'dbe's treat! He's ſuch a pretty fellow, and you like him ſo well, I wonder you won't go to drink his liquor.

sp.speaker: Capt. P.
sp.p:
Aye, aye, very ſtrange: but your friends Strutabout and Smallhopes, I like ſo little as never
to take a glaſs from them, becauſe I ſhall never pay the price which is always expected for it, by voting againſt my conſcience: I therefore don't go, to avoid being aſked for what I won't give.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: A very diſtereſs motive, truly, but for the matter of that, you've not ſo much to boaſt of your friend Wou'dbe, if what I have been told of him is true; for I have heard ſay, he and the fine beaſt of a gentleman, Sir John Toddy, have joined intereſs. Mr. Wou'dbe, I was creditly 'formed, was known for to ſay, he wouldn't ſerve for a burgeſs, unleſs Sir John was elected with him.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: What's that you ſay, neighbour? has Mr. Wou'dbe and Sir John joined intereſt?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Yes, they have; and ant there a clever fellow for ye? a rare burgeſs you will have, when a fellow gets in, who will go drunk, and be a ſleeping in the houſe! I wiſh people wouldn't pretend for to hold up their heads ſo high, who have ſuch friends and aſſociates. There's poor Mr. Smallhopes, who iſn't as much attended to, is a very proper gentleman, and is no drunkard, and has no drunken companions.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: I don't believe it. Mr. Wou'dbe's a cleverer man than that, and people ought to be aſhamed to went ſuch ſlanders.

sp.speaker: 2d Freeholder.
sp.p: So I ſay: and as we are of one mind, let's go ſtrait, and let Mr. Wou'dbe know it.

sp.speaker: 3d Freeholder.
sp.p: If Mr. Wou'dbe did ſay it, I won't vote for him, that's ſartain.

sp.speaker: 4th Freeholder.
sp.p: Are you ſure of it, neighbour?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Yes, I am ſure of it: d'ye think I'd ſpeak ſuch a thing without having good authority?

sp.speaker: 4th Freeholder.
sp.p:
I'm ſorry for't; come neighbour,
(to the 3d Freeholder)
this is the worſt news that I've heard for a long time.
Exeunt 3d & 4th Freeholder.

sp.speaker: 5th Freeholder.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear it. Sir John Toddy is a clever open-hearted gentleman as I ever knew, one that wont turn his back upon a poor man, but will take a chearful cup with one as well as another, and it does honour to Mr. Wou'dbe to prefer ſuch a one, to any of your whifflers who han't the heart to be generous, and yet deſpiſe poor folks. Huzza! for Mr. Wou'dbe and for Sir John Toddy.

sp.speaker: 6th Freeholder.
sp.p: I think ſo too, neighbour. Mr. Wou'dbe, I always thought, was a man of ſenſe, and had larning, as they call it, but he did not love diverſion enough, I like him the better for't. Huzza for Mr. Wou'dbe and Sir John Toddy.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Wou'dbe and Sir John Toddy. Wou'dbe and Toddy, for ever, boys! Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Capt. Paunch.
sp.p: The man that heard it is miſtaken, for Mr. Wou'dbe never ſaid it.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I'll lay you a bowl he did.

sp.speaker: Capt. P.
sp.p: Done.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Done, ſir, Oh! Jack Sly, Jack Sly.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: (without) Halloa.

div.stage: Enter Jack, ſaying, who call'd me? what's your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: (winking to Jack). I have laid a bowl with the Captain here, that Mr. Wou'dbe did ſay, that he would not ſerve as a burgeſs, unleſs Sir John Toddy was elected with him.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I have heard as much, and more that's little to his credit. He has hurt us more than he'll do us good for one while. It's his doings our levies are ſo high.

sp.speaker: Capt. P.
sp.p: Out upon you, if that's your proof, fetch the bowl. Why, gentlemen, if I had a mind, I could ſay as much and more of the other candidates. But, gentlemen, 'tis not fair play: don't abuſe our friend, and we'll let your's alone. Mr. Wou'dbe is a clever gentleman, and perhaps ſo are the reſt: let every man vote as he pleaſes, and let's raiſe no ſtories to the prejudice of either.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Damn me, if I don't ſpeak my mind. Wou'dbe ſhan't go if I can help it, by God, for I boldly ſay, Mr. Wou'dbe has done us more harm, than he will ever do us good, (raiſing his voice very high). Exeunt into the houſe.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: So ſay I. Exit after him.

sp.speaker: Capt. P.
sp.p: Go along: bawl your hearts out: nobody will mind you, I hope. Well, I rejoice that Mr. Wou'dbe is determined ſtill to ſerve us. If he does us no good, he will do us no harm. Mr. Strutabout would do very well if he was not ſuch a coxcomb. As for Smallhopes, I'd as ſoon ſend to New-Market, for a burgeſs, as ſend him, and old Sir John loves tipple too well: egad, I'll give Wou'dbe my vote, and throw away the other. Exit.

div.head: SCENE III. Wou'dbe's houſe.
div.stage: Enter Wou'dbe, looking at a letter.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p:
This note gives me information, that the people are much diſpleaſed with me for declaring in
favour of Sir John Toddy. Who could propagate this report, I know not, but was not this abroad, ſomething elſe would be reported, as prejudicial to my intereſt; I muſt take an opportunity of juſtifying myſelf in public.

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: Mr. Strutabout waits upon your honour.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Deſire him to walk in.

sp.speaker: Strutabout.
sp.p: Mr. Wou'dbe, your ſervant. Conſidering the buſineſs now in hand, I think you confine yourſelf too much at home. There are ſeveral little reports circulating to your diſadvantage, and as a friend, I would adviſe you to ſhew yourſelf to the people, and endeavour to confute them.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I believe, ſir, I am indebted to my brother candidates, for moſt of the reports that are propagated to my diſadvantage, but I hope, Mr. Strutabout is a man of too much honour, to ſay any thing in my abſence, that he cannot make appear.

sp.speaker: Strutabout.
sp.p: That you may depend on, ſir. But there are ſome who are ſo intent upon taking your place, that they will ſtick at nothing to obtain their ends.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Are you in the ſecret, ſir?

sp.speaker: Strutabout.
sp.p:
So far, ſir, that I have had overtures from Mr. Smallhopes and his friends, to join my intereſt with their's, againſt you. This, I rejected with diſdain, being conſcious that you were the propereſt perſon to ſerve the county; but when Smallhopes told me, he intended to prejudice your intereſt by ſcattering a few ſtories among the people, to your diſadvantage,
it raiſed my blood to ſuch a pitch, that had he not promiſed me to be ſilent, I believe I ſhould have chaſtiſed him for you myſelf.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: If, ſir, you were ſo far my friend, I am obliged to you: though whatever report he is the author of, will, I am certain, gain little credit with the people.

sp.speaker: Strutabout.
sp.p: I believe ſo; and therefore, if you are willing, we'll join our intereſts together, and ſoon convince the fellow, that by attacking you he has injured himſelf.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: So far from joining with you, or any body elſe, or endeavouring to procure a vote for you, I am determined never to aſk a vote for myſelf, or receive one that is unduly obtained.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: Maſter, rare news, here's our neighbour Guzzle, as drunk as ever Chief Juſtice Cornelius was upon the bench.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: That's no news, Ralpho: but do you call it rare news, that a creature in the ſhape of man, and endued with the faculties of reaſon, ſhould ſo far debaſe the workmanſhip of heaven, by making his carcaſe a receptacle for ſuch pollution?

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: Maſter, you are hard upon neighbour Guzzle: our Juſtices gets drunk, and why not poor Guzzle? But, ſir, he wants to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Tell him to come in. (exit Ralpho). All muſt be made welcome now.

div.stage: Re-enter Ralpho and Guzzle, with an empty bottle.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Ha! Mr. Wou'dbe, how is it?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I'm ſomething more in my ſenſes than you, John, tho' not ſo ſenſible as you would have me, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: If I can make you ſenſible how much I want my bottle filled, and how much I ſhall love the contents, it's all the ſenſes I deſire you to have.

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: If I may be allowed to ſpeak, neighbour Guzzle, you are wrong; his honour ſits up for a burgeſs, and ſhould have five ſenſes at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Five ſenſes! how, what five?

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: Why, neighbour, you know, eating, drinking, and ſleeping are three; t'other two are beſt known to myſelf.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I'm ſorry Mr. Guzzle, you are ſo ignorant of the neceſſary qualifications of a member of the houſe of burgeſſes.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Why, you old dog, I knew before Ralpho told me. To convince you, eating, drinking and ſleeping, are three; fighting and lying are t'others.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Why fighting and lying?

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Why, becauſe you are not fit for a burgeſs, unleſs you'll fight; ſuppoſe a man that values himſelf upon boxing, ſhould ſtand in the lobby, ready cock'd and prim'd, and knock you down, and bung up both your eyes for a fortnight, you'd be aſhamed to ſhew your face in the houſe, and be living at our expence all the time.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Why lying?

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p:
Becauſe, when you have been at Williamſburg, for ſix or ſeven weeks, under pretence of ſerving your county, and come back, ſays I to you, what news? none at all, ſays you; what have you
been about? ſays I,—ſays you—and ſo you muſt tell ſome damned lie, ſooner than ſay you have been doing nothing.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: No, Guzzle, I'll make it a point of duty to diſpatch the buſineſs, and my ſtudy to promote the good of my county.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Yes, damn it, you all promiſe mighty fair, but the devil a bit do you perform; there's Strutabout, now, he'll promiſe to move mountains. He'll make the rivers navigable, and bring the tide over the tops of the hills, for a vote.

sp.speaker: Strutabout.
sp.p: You may depend, Mr. Guzzle, I'll perform whatever I promiſe.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: I don't believe it, damn me if I like you.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Don't be angry, John, let our actions hereafter be the teſt of our inclinations to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Agreed, Mr. Wou'dbe, but that fellow that ſlunk off juſt now, I've no opinion of.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: (Looking about) what, is Mr. Strutabout gone? why, ſurely, Guzzle, you did not put him to flight?

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe I did, but no matter, (holding up his bottle, and looking at it,) my bottle never was ſo long a filling in this houſe, before; ſurely, there's a leak in the bottom, (looks at it again).

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: What have you got in your bottle, John, a lizard?

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Yes, a very uncommon one, and I want a little rum put to it, to preſerve it.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Hav'n't you one in your belly, John?

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: A dozen, I believe, by their twiſting, when I mentioned the rum.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Would you have rum to preſerve them, too?

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Mr. Wou'dbe, by all means; but, why ſo much talk about it, if you intend to do it, do it at once, man, for I am in a damnable hurry.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Do what? who are to be burgeſſes, John?

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Who are to be what? (looking angry).

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Burgeſſes, who are you for?

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: For the firſt man that fills my bottle: ſo Mr. Wou'dbe, your ſervant. Exit Guzzle.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Ralpho, go after him, and fill his bottle.

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: Maſter, we ought to be careful of the rum, elſe 'twill not hold out, (aſide) it's always a feaſt or a famine with us; maſter has juſt got a little Jamaica for his own uſe, and now he muſt ſpill it, and ſpare it till there's not a drop left. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: (pulling out his watch.) 'Tis now the time a friend of mine has appointed for me to meet the freeholders at a barbecue; well, I find, in order to ſecure a ſeat in our auguſt ſenate, 'tis neceſſary a man ſhould either be a ſlave or a fool; a ſlave to the people, for the privilege of ſerving them, and a fool himſelf, for thus begging a troubleſome and expenſive employment.

lg.l: To ſigh, while toddy-toping ſots rejoice,
To ſee you paying for their empty voice,
From morn to night your humble head decline,
To 〈◊〉 an honour that is juſtly thine,

I •
〈◊〉 a fool, who's your's at this day's treat,
And next another's, if another's meat,
Is all the bliſs a candidate acquires,
In all his wiſhes, or his vain deſires.

div.head: SCENE I. A race-field, a bullock, and ſeveral hogs barbecued.
div.stage: Twiſt, Stern, Prize, Lucy, Catharine, and Sarah, ſitting on four fence rails.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, what do you think of Mr. Strutabout, and Mr. Smallhopes? it ſeems one of the old ones declines, and t'other, I believe, might as well, if what neighbour Sly ſays, is true.

sp.speaker: Stern.
sp.p: Pray, gentlemen, what plauſible objection have you againſt Mr. Wou'dbe? he's a clever civil gentleman as any, and as far as my poor weak capacity can go, he's a man of as good learning, and knows the punctilios of behaving himſelf, with the beſt of them.

sp.speaker: Prize.
sp.p: Wou'dbe, for ſartin, is a civil gentleman, but he can't ſpeak his mind ſo boldly as Mr. Strutabout, and commend me to a man that will ſpeak his mind freely;—I ſay.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, commend me to Mr. Wou'dbe, I ſay,—I nately like the man; he's mighty good to all his poor neighbours, and when he comes into a poor body's houſe, he's ſo free and ſo funny, is'nt he, old man? (ſpeaking to Twiſt).

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: A little too free ſometimes, faith; he was funny when he wanted to ſee the colour of your garters; wa'nt he?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! for ſhame, huſband. Mr. Wou'dbe has no more harm about him, than a ſucking babe; at leaſt, if he has, I never ſaw it.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: Nor felt it, I hope; but wife, you and I, you know, could never agree about burgeſſes.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: If the wives were to vote, I believe they would make a better choice than their huſbands.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: You'd be for the funnyeſt—wou'dn't you?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, faith; and the wittieſt, and prettieſt, and the wiſeſt, and the beſt too; you are all for ugly except when you choſe me.

sp.speaker: Catharine.
sp.p: Well done, Lucy, you are right, girl. If we were all to ſpeak to our old men as freely as you do, there would be better doings.

sp.speaker: Stern.
sp.p: Perhaps not, Kate.

sp.speaker: Catharine.
sp.p: I am ſure there would; for if a clever gentleman, now-a-days, only gives a body a gingercake in a civil way, you are ſullen for a week about it. Remember when Mr. Wou'dbe promiſed Molly a riband, and pair of buckles, you would not let the poor girl have 'em: but you take toddy from him;—yes, and you'll drink a little too much, you know, Richard.

sp.speaker: Stern.
sp.p: Well, it's none of our coſts, if I do.

sp.speaker: Catharine.
sp.p: Huſband, you know Mr. Wou'dbe is a clever gentleman; he has been a good friend to us.

sp.speaker: Stern.
sp.p: I agree to it, and can vote for him without your claſh.

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.p: I'll be bound when it comes to the pinch, they'll all vote for him: won't you old man? he ſtood for our George, when our neighbour refuſed us.

sp.speaker: Prize.
sp.p: Mr. Wou'dbe's a man well enough in his neighbourhood, and he may have learning, as they ſay he has, but he don't ſhew it like Mr. Strutabout.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Your ſervant, gentlemen, (ſhakes hands all round) we have got fine weather, thank God: how are crops with you? we are very dry in our parts.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: We are very dry here; Mr. Guzzle, where's your friend Sir John, and Mr. Wou'dbe? they are to treat to-day, I hear.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: I wiſh I could ſee it, but there are more treats beſides their's; where's your friend Mr. Strutabout? I heard we were to have a treat from Smallhopes and him to-day.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: Fine times, boys. Some of them had better keep their money; I'll vote for no man but to my liking.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: If I may be ſo bold, pray, which way is your liking?

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: Not as your's is, I believe; but nobody ſhall know my mind till the day.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Very good, Mr. Twiſt; nobody, I hope, will put themſelves to the trouble to aſk.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: You have taken the trouble already.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: No harm, I hope, ſir.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: None at all, ſir: Yonder comes Sir John, and quite ſober, as I live.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Gentlemen and ladies, your ſervant, hah! my old friend Prize, how goes it? how does your wife and children do?

sp.speaker: Sarah.
sp.p: At your ſervice, ſir. (making a low courtſey.)

sp.speaker: Prize.
sp.p: How the devil come he to know me ſo well, and never ſpoke to me before in his life? (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: (whiſpering Sir John) Dick Stern.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Hah! Mr. Stern, I'm proud to ſee you; I hope your family are well; how many children? does the good woman keep to the old ſtroke?

sp.speaker: Catharine.
sp.p: Yes, an't pleaſe your honour, I hope my lady's well, with your honour.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: At your ſervice, madam.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: (whiſpering Sir John) Roger Twiſt.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Hah! Mr. Roger Twiſt! your ſervant, ſir. I hope your wife and children are well.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: There's my wife. I have no children, at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A pretty girl: why, Roger, if you don't do better, you muſt call an old fellow to your aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: I have enough to aſſiſt me, without applying to you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No offence, I hope, ſir; excuſe my freedom.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: None at all, ſir; Mr. Wou'dbe is ready to befriend me in that way at any time.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Not in earneſt, I hope, ſir; tho' he's a damn'd fellow, I believe.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Why, Roger, if you talk at this rate, people will think you are jealous; for ſhame of yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Twiſt
sp.p: For ſhame of yourſelf, you mean.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: A truce, a truce—here comes Mr. Wou'dbe.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your ſervant. Why, Sir John, you have entered the liſt, it ſeems; and are determined to whip over the ground, if you are treated with a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'm not to be diſtanc'd by you, or a dozen ſuch.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: There's nothing like courage upon theſe occaſions; but you were out when you choſe me to ride for you, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Let's have no more of your algebra, nor proverbs, here.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Come, gentlemen, you are both friends, I hope.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: While Sir John confined himſelf to his bottle and dogs, and moved only in his little circle of pot-companions, I could be with him; but ſince his folly has induced him to offer himſelf a candidate for a place, for which he is not fit, I muſt ſay, I deſpiſe him. The people are of opinion, that I favour this undertaking of his; but I now declare, he is not the man I wiſh the people to elect.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, who gave you a right to chooſe for us?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I have no right to chooſe for you; but I have a right to give my opinion: eſpecially when I am the ſuppoſed author of Sir John's folly.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Perhaps he's no greater fool than ſome others.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p:
It would be ungrateful in you, Mr. Guzzle, not to ſpeak in favour of Sir John; for you
have ſtored away many gallons of his liquor in that bel • y of your's.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: And he's the cleverer gentleman for it; is not he, neighbours?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: For ſartin; it's no diſparagement to drink with a poor fellow.

sp.speaker: 2d Freeholder.
sp.p: No more it is, tho' ſome of the quality are mighty proud that way.

sp.speaker: 3d Freeholder.
sp.p: Mr. Wou'dbe ſhou'd'n't ſpeak ſo freely againſt that.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: Mr. Wou'dbe.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: We have heard a ſartin report, that you and Sir John have joined intereſt.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Well; do you believe it?

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: Why, it don't look much like it now, Mr. Wou'dbe; but, mayhap, it's only a copy of your countenance.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: You may put what conſtruction you pleaſe upon my behaviour, gentlemen; but I aſſure you, it never was my intention to join with Sir John, or any one elſe.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: Moreover, I've heard a 'ſponſible man ſay, he could prove you were the cauſe of theſe new taxes.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Do you believe that too? or can you believe that it's in the power of any individual member to make a law himſelf? If a law is enacted that is diſpleaſing to the people, it has the concurrence of the whole legiſlative body, and my vote for, or againſt it, is of little conſequence.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: And what the devil good do you do then?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: As much as I have abilities to do.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Suppoſe, Mr. Wou'dbe, we were to want you to get the price of rum lower'd—wou'd you do it?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I cou'd not.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Huzza for Sir John! he has promiſed to do it, huzza for Sir John!

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: Suppoſe, Mr. Wou'dbe, we ſhould want this tax taken off—cou'd you do it?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I could not.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Strutabout! he's damn'd, if he don't. Huzza for Mr. Strutabout!

sp.speaker: Stern.
sp.p: Suppoſe, Mr. Wou'dbe, we that live over the river, ſhould want to come to church on this ſide, is it not very hard we ſhould pay ferryage; when we pay as much to the church as you do?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Very hard.

sp.speaker: Stern.
sp.p: Suppoſe we were to petition the aſſembly could you get us clear of that expence?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I believe it to be juſt; and make no doubt but it would paſs into a law.

sp.speaker: Stern.
sp.p: Will you do it?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I will endeavour to do it.

sp.speaker: Stern.
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Wou'dbe! Wou'dbe forever!

sp.speaker: Prize.
sp.p: Why don't you burgeſſes, do ſomething with the damn'd pickers? If we have a hogſhead of tobacco refuſed, away it goes to them; and after they have twiſted up the beſt of it for their own uſe, and taken as much as will pay them for their trouble, the poor planter has little for his ſhare.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: There are great complaints againſt them; and I believe the aſſembly will take them under conſideration.

sp.speaker: Prize.
sp.p: Will you vote againſt them?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I will, if they deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Prize.
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Wou'dbe! you ſhall go, old fellow; don't be afraid; I'll warrant it.

div.stage: Exeunt ſeverally; ſome huzzaing for Mr. Wou'dbe —ſome for Sir John—ſome for Mr. Strutabout.

div.head: SCENE II. Another part of the field.
div.stage: Mr. Strutabout, Mr. Smallhopes, and a number of freeholders round them.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Strutabout!

sp.speaker: 2d Freeholder.
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Smallhopes!

sp.speaker: 3d Freeholder.
sp.p: Hazza for Mr. Smallhopes and Mr. Strutabout!

sp.speaker: 4th Freeholder
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Strutabout and Mr. Smallhopes! Exeunt, huzzaing.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Huzza for Sir John Toddy, the clevereſt gentleman—the fineſt gentleman that ever was (hickuping.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Guzzle.
sp.p: Where's my drunken beaſt of a huſband? (hickups) Oh John Guzzle, Oh John Guzzle.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: What the devil do you want?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Guzzle.
sp.p: Why don't you go home, you drunken beaſt? Lord bleſs me, how the gingerbread has given me the hickup.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Why, Joan, you have made too—free with the bottle—I believe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Guzzle.
sp.p: I make free with the bottle—you drunken ſot!—Well, well, the gingerbread has made me quite giddy.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Hold up, Joan, don't fall— (Mrs. Guzzle falls.) The devil, you will? Joan! why woman, what's the matter? are you drunk?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Guzzle.
sp.p: Drunk! you beaſt! No, quite ſober; but very ſick with eating ginger-bread.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: For ſhame, Joan; get up— (offers to help her up, and falls upon her.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Guzzle.
sp.p: Oh Lord! John! you've almoſt killed me.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Not I—I'll get clear of you as faſt as I can.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Guzzle.
sp.p: Oh John, I ſhall die, I ſhall die.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Very well, you'll die a pleaſant death, then.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Guzzle.
sp.p: Oh Lord! how ſick! how ſick!

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Oh Joan Guzzle! Oh Joan Guz-zle!— Why don't you go home, you drunken beaſt. Lord bleſs me, how the gingerbread has given me the hickup.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Guzzle.
sp.p: Pray, my dear John, help me up.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Pray, my dear Joan, get ſober firſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Guzzle.
sp.p: Pray John, help me up.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Pray, Joan, go to ſleep; and when I am as drunk as you, I'll come and take your place. Farewell, Joan. Huzza for Sir John Toddy!

div.stage: Scene changes to another part of the field. Strutabout, Smallhopes, and freeholders.

sp.speaker: Strutabout.
sp.p:
Gentlemen—I'm much obliged to you
for your good intentions; I make no doubt but (with the aſſiſtance of my friend Mr. Smallhopes) I ſhall be able to do every thing you have requeſted. Your grievances ſhall be redreſs'd; and all your petitions heard.

sp.speaker: Freeholders.
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Strutabout and Mr. Smallhopes!

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your ſervant; you ſeem happy in a circle of your friends, I hope my company is not diſagreeable.

sp.speaker: Strutabout.
sp.p: It can't be very agreeable to thoſe you have treated ſo ill.

sp.speaker: Smallhopes.
sp.p: You have uſed me ill, and all this company, by God—

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: If I have, Gentlemen, I am ſorry for it; but it never was my intention to treat any perſon ungenteelly.

sp.speaker: Smallhopes.
sp.p: You be damn'd; you're a turn-coat, by God.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Your abuſe will never have any weight with me: neither do I regard your oaths or imprecations. In order to ſupport a weak cauſe, you ſwear to what requires better proof than your aſſertions.

sp.speaker: Smallhopes.
sp.p: Where's your friend, Sir John Toddy? he's a pretty fellow, an't he, and be damn'd to you; you recommend him to the people, don't you?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: No, ſir; I ſhould be as blamable to recommend Sir John, as you, and your friend there (pointing to Strutabout) in recommending one another.

sp.speaker: Strutabout.
sp.p:
Sir, I am as capable of ſerving the people
as yourſelf; and let me tell you, ſir, my ſole intention in offering myſelf is, that I may redreſs the many and heavy grievances you have impoſed upon this poor county.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Poor, indeed, when you are believed, or when coxcombs and jockies can impoſe themſelves upon it for men of learning.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: Well, its no uſe; Mr. Wou'dbe is too hard for them both.

sp.speaker: 2d Freeholder.
sp.p: I think ſo too: why Strutabout! ſpeak up, old fellow, or you'll loſe ground.

sp.speaker: Strutabout.
sp.p: I'll lay you fifty pounds I'm elected before you.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Betting will not determine it; and therefore I ſhall not lay.

sp.speaker: Strutabout.
sp.p: I can lick you, Wou'dbe, (beginning to ſtrip.)

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: You need not ſtrip to do it; for you intend to do it with your tongue, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Smallhopes.
sp.p: (clapping Strutabout upon the back) Well done Strutabout,—you can do it, by God. Don't be afraid, you ſhan't be hurt; damn me if you ſhall, (ſtrips.)

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: What! Gentlemen, do they who aſpire to the firſt poſts in our county, and who have ambition to become legiſlators, and to take upon themſelves part of the guidance of the ſtate, ſubmit their naked bodies to public view, as if they were malefactors; or, for ſome crimes, condemned to the whipping-poſt?

sp.speaker: Smallhopes.
sp.p: Come on, damn ye; and don't preach your damn'd proverbs here.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Are the candidates to fight for their ſeats in the houſe of burgeſſes. If ſo, perhaps I may ſtand as good a chance to ſucceed, as you.

sp.speaker: Smallhopes.
sp.p: I can lick you, by God. Come on, if you dare— (capering about.)

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: Up to him—I'll ſtand by you. (to Wou'dbe.)

sp.speaker: 2d Freeholder.
sp.p: They are not worth your notice, Mr. Wou'dbe; but if you have a mind to try yourſelf, I'll ſee fair play.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: When I think they have ſufficiently expoſed themſelves, I'll explain the opinion I have of them, with the end of my cane.

sp.speaker: Smallhopes.
sp.p: Up to him, damn ye, (puſhing Strutabout.)

sp.speaker: Strutabout.
sp.p: You need not puſh me, I can fight without being puſhed to it; fight yourſelf, if you are ſo fond of it. (putting on his cloaths.)

sp.speaker: Smallhopes.
sp.p: Nay, if you are for that, and determined to be a coward, Mr. Strutabout, I can't help it; but damn me if I ever hack. (putting on his cloaths.)

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: So you are both ſcared, gentlemen, without a blow, or an angry look! ha, ha, ha! Well, gentlemen, you have eſcaped a good caning, and though you are not fit for burgeſſes, you'll make good ſoldiers; for you are excellent at a retreat.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Wou'dbe!

sp.speaker: 2d Freeholder.
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Wou'dbe!

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Huzza for Sir John Toddy! Toddy (hickups) forever, boys!

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Here he comes—as fine gentleman, tho' I ſay it, as the beſt of them.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: So I am, John, as clever a fellow (hickups) as the famous Mr. Wou'dbe, tho' I (hickups) ſay it.

sp.speaker: Strutabout.
sp.p: There's a pretty fellow to be a burgeſs, gentleman: lord, what a drunken beaſt it is.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What beaſt, pray? am I a beaſt?

sp.speaker: Strutabout.
sp.p: Yes, Sir John, you are a beaſt, and you may take the name of what beaſt you pleaſe; ſo your ſervant, my dear. Exeunt Strutabout and Smallhopes.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Except an aſs, Sir John, for that he's entitled to.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Thank you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: A friend in need, Sir John, as the proverb ſays, is a friend indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I thank you, I know you are my friend (hickups) Mr. Wou'dbe, if you'd ſpeak your mind— I know you are.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: How do you know it, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Did not you take my part juſt now, Mr. Wou'dbe? (hickups) I know it.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I ſhall always take your part, Sir John, when you are impoſed upon by a greater ſcoundrel than yourſelf, and when you pretend to what you are not fit for, I ſhall always oppoſe you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Wou'dbe, an't I as fitten a (hickups) man as either of thoſe?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: More ſo, Sir John, for they are knaves, and you, Sir John, are an honeſt blockhead.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Is that in my favour, or not, John? (to Guzzle.)

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: In your favour, by all means; for (hickups) he ſays you are honeſt. Huzza for Mr. Wou'dbe and the honeſt (hickups) Sir John Blockhead.

div.stage: Enter Ralpho—gives a letter to Wou'dbe.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: (Reads) —this is good news indeed.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Wou'dbe!

sp.speaker: 2d Freeholder.
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Wou'dbe!

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Huzza for the honeſt Sir John Blockhead. (hickups)

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p:
Silence, gentlemen, and I'll read a letter to you, that (I don't doubt) will give you great pleaſure. (he reads)
Sir, I have been informed that the ſcoundrels who oppoſed us laſt election (not content with n • reſignation) are endeavouring to undermine you in the g • od opinion of the people: It has warmed my blood, and • in call'd my thoughts from retirement; ſpeak this to the people, and let them know I intend to ſtand a poll, &c.
Your's affectionately. WORTHY.

sp.speaker: Freeholders.
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Wou'dbe and Mr. Worthy!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Huzza for Mr. Worthy and Mr. Wou'dbe! (hickups) I'm not ſo fitten as they, and therefore gentlemen I recline. (hickups) Yes, gentlemen (ſtaggering about) I will; for I am not (hickups) ſo fitten as they. (falls)

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Huzza for the drunken Sir John Toddy! (hickups)

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Help me up John—do, John, help.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: No, Sir John, ſtay, and I'll fetch my wife, • n, and lay—her along ſide of you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Ralpho.

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Take care of Sir John, leaſt any accident ſhould befall him.

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: Yes, ſir. Exeunt Wou'dbe and freeholders, huzzaing for Wou'dbe and Worthy.

div.stage: Enter Guzzle, with his wife in his arms.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Here, Sir John, here's my wife faſt aſleep, to keep you company, and as drunk as a ſow. (throws her upon Sir John, and returns to one ſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh Lord! you've broke my bones.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: (waking) John! John! (punching Sir John) get up; (looking round, ſees Sir John) what have we here? Lord, what would our John give to know this? He would have reaſon to be jealous of me, then!

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Well, Joan, are you ſober?

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: (getting up) How came that man to be lying with me? it's ſome of your doings, I'm ſure; that you may have an excuſe to be jealous of me.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: I want no excuſe for that, child.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: What brought him there?

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: The ſame that brought you, child; rum, ſugar, and water.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: Well, well, as I live, I thought it was you, and that we were in our own clean ſweet bed. Lord! how I tremble for fear he ſhould have done what you do, ſometimes, John.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: I never do any thing when I am drunk. Sir John and you have done more than that, I believe.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: Don't be jealous, John; it will ruin us both.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: I am very jealous of that.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: If you are, I'll beat the cruel beaſt that is the cauſe of it, 'till he ſatisfies you I am innocent.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Don't, Joan, it will make me more jealous.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: I will, I tell you I will. (beats Sir John, who all the time cries murder, help, help!)

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: Stop, madam, this gentleman is in my care; and you muſt not abuſe him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Guzzle.
sp.p: I will, and you too, you raſcal. (beats him firſt, and then Sir John.)

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: Peace, ſtop, madam, peace, peace.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh lord! help, John, for God's ſake, help.

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: Do as you pleaſe, madam, do as you pleaſe. (runs off).

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: (beating Sir John) I'll learn you to cuckold a man without letting his wife know it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Help, murder! help.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: (taking hold of Joan) Stop, Joan, I'm ſatisfied—quite ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: What fellow is it?

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Sir John Toddy, our good friend; Oh, Joan, you ſhould not have beat poor Sir John, he is as drunk as you and I were, Joan. Oh! poor Sir John. (cries.)

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: Good lack, why did'nt you tell me? I would have ſtruck you as ſoon as him, John. Don't be angry, good Sir John, I did not know you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: It's well enough: help me out of the mire, neighbours, and I'll forget and forgive.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p:
Yes, Sir John, and ſo we will, (they help him up.) Come, Sir John, let's go home, this is no
place for us: come Joan. [Exeunt Guzzle and Joan, ſupporting Sir John.]

div.head: SCENE III. Another part of the field.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Where's Sir John?

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: In the hands of a woman, ſir, and as I left him in ſuch good hands, I thought there was no farther occaſion for my attendance.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Are you ſure he'll be taken care of?

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: Yes, the lady, an't pleaſe your honour, ſeemed deviliſh kind to him.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: See that you have all ready; its high time we thought of going home, if we intend there to-night.

sp.speaker: Ralpho.
sp.p: All ſhall be ready, ſir. Exit Ralpho.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Well, I've felt the pulſe of all the leading men, and find they beat ſtill for Worthy, and myſelf. Strutabout and Smallhopes fawn and cringe in ſo abject a manner, for the few votes they get, that I'm in hopes they'll be ſoon heartily deſpiſed.

lg.l: The prudent candidate who hopes to riſe,
Ne'er deigns to hide it, in a mean diſguiſe.
Will, to his place, with moderation ſlide,
And win his way, or not reſiſt the tide.
The fool, aſpiring to bright honour's poſt,
In noiſe, in ſhouts, and tumults oft, is loſt.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Nothing could have afforded me more pleaſure than your letter; I read it to the people, and can with pleaſure aſſure you, it gave them infinite ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: My ſole motive in declaring myſelf was to ſerve you, and if I am the means of your gaining your election with honour, I ſhall be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: You have always been extremely kind, ſir, but I could not enjoy the ſucceſs I promiſed myſelf, without your participation.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: I have little inclination to the ſervice; you know my averſion to a public life, Wou'dbe, and how little I have ever courted the people for the troubleſome office they have hitherto impoſed upon me.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I believe you enjoy as much domeſtic happineſs as any perſon, and that your averſion to a public life proceeds from the pleaſure you find at home. But, ſir, it ſurely is the duty of every man who has abilities to ſerve his country, to take up the burden, and bear it with patience.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: I know it is needleſs to argue with you upon this head: you are determined I ſhall ſerve with you, I find.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I am; and therefore let's take the propereſt methods to inſure ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: What would you propoſe?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe▪
sp.p: Nothing more than for you to ſhew yourſelf to the people.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: I'll attend you where ever you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: To-morrow being the day of election, I have invited moſt of the principal freeholders to breakfaſt with me, in their way to the court-houſe, I hope you'll favour us with your company.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: I will; till then, adieu. Exit Worthy.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: I ſhall expect you. It would give me great pleaſure if Worthy would be more anxious than he appears to be upon this occaſion; conſcious of his abilities and worth, he ſcorns to aſk a vote for any perſon but me; well, I muſt turn the tables on him, and ſolicit as ſtrongly in his favour.

lg.l: 'Tis ſaid ſelf-intereſt is the ſecret aim,
Of thoſe uniting under Friendſhip's name.
How true this maxim is, let others prove—
Myſelf I'd puniſh for the man I love.

div.head: SCENE II. Mr. Julip's houſe.
div.stage: Enter Captain Paunch and Mr. Julip.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, neighbour, I have come to ſee you on purpoſe to know how votes went at the treat yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Julip.
sp.p: I was not there; but I've ſeen neighbour Guzzle this morning, and he ſays, Sir John gives the matter up to Mr. Worthy and Mr. Wou'dbe

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Mr. Worthy! does he declare, huzza, my boys! well, I'm proud our county may chooſe two without being obliged to have one of thoſe jackanapes at the head of it, faith: Who are you for now, neighbour?

sp.speaker: Julip.
sp.p:
I believe I ſhall vote for the two old ones, and tho' I ſaid I was for Sir John, it was becauſe I
lik'd neither of the others; but ſince Mr. Worthy will ſerve us, why, to be ſartin its our duty to ſend Wou'dbe and him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hah, faith, now you ſpeak like a man; you are a man after my own heart: give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Julip.
sp.p: Here it is, Wou'dbe and Worthy, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Done, but who comes yonder? ſurely, it's not Mr. Worthy! 'Tis, I declare.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your ſervant, I hope your families are well.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: At your ſervice, ſir.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: I need not, I ſuppoſe, gentlemen, inform you that I have entered the liſt with my old competitors, and have determined to ſtand a poll at the next election. If you were in the croud yeſterday, my friend Wou'dbe, I doubt not, made a declaration of my intentions to the people.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: We know it, thank heaven, Mr. Worthy, tho' neither of us were there: as I did not like ſome of the candidates I did not chooſe to be perſecuted for a vote that I was reſolved never to beſtow upon them.

sp.speaker: Julip.
sp.p: My rule is never to taſte of a man's liquor unleſs I'm his friend, and therefore, I ſtay'd at home.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: Well, my honeſt friend, I am proud to find that you ſtill preſerve your uſual independence. Is it poſſible Captain, that the people can be ſo miſſed, as to reject Wou'dbe, and elect Strutabout in his room?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
You know, Mr. Worthy, how it is, as long as the liquor is running, ſo long they'll be Mr. Strutabout's
friends, but when the day comes, I'm thinking it will be another caſe.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: I'm ſorry, my countymen, for the ſake of a little toddy, can be induced to behave in a manner ſo contradictory to the candour and integrity which always ſhould prevail among mankind.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It's ſo, ſir, you may depend upon it.

sp.speaker: Julip.
sp.p: I'm a thinking it is.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, will you give me leave to aſk you. how far you think my declaring will be of ſervice to Mr. Wou'dbe?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Your declaring has already ſilenced Sir John Toddy; and I doubt not, but Strutabout and Smallhopes will loſe many votes by it.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: Has Sir John declined? poor Sir John is a weak man, but he has more virtues to recommend him than either of the others.

sp.speaker: Julip.
sp.p: So I think, Mr. Worthy, and I'll be ſo bold as to tell you that, had you not ſet up, Mr. Wou'dbe and Sir John ſhould have had my vote.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: Was I a conſtituent, inſtead of a candidate, I ſhould do the ſame.

sp.speaker: Julip.
sp.p: Well, captain, you ſee I was not ſo much to blame.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sir John maybe honeſt, but he is no fitter for that place than myſelf.

sp.speaker: Julip.
sp.p: Suppoſe he was not, if he was the beſt that offered to ſerve us, ſhould not we chooſe him.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: Yes, ſurely: Well, my friends, I'm now on my way, to breakfaſt at Mr. Wou'dbe's, but I hope to meet you at the court-houſe to day.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Aye, aye, depend upon us. Exit Worthy.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, neighbour, I hope things now go on better; I like the preſent appearance.

sp.speaker: Julip.
sp.p: So do I.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Do all you can, old fellow.

sp.speaker: Julip.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I hope you will, neighbour. I wiſh you well.

sp.speaker: Julip.
sp.p: You the ſame. ſhake hands, and exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III. Woud'be's houſe, a long breakfaſt table ſet out.
div.stage: Wou'dbe, Worthy, Capt. Paunch, Mr. Julip, Twiſt, Stern, Prize, and other freeholders; ſeveral negroes go backwards and forwards, bringing in the breakfaſt.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: Give us your hand, neighbour Worthy, I'm extremely glad to ſee thee with all my heart: So my heart of oak, you are willing to give your time and trouble once more to the ſervice of your country.

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: Your kindneſs does me honour, and if my labours be productive of good to my country, I ſhall deem myſelf fortunate.

sp.speaker: 2d Freeholder.
sp.p: Still the ſame ſenſible man I always thought him. Damn it, now if every county cou'd but ſend ſuch a burgeſs, what a noble houſe we ſhould have?

sp.speaker: 3d Freeholder.
sp.p: We ſhall have no polling now, but all will be for the ſame, I believe. Here's neighbour Twiſt, who was reſolute for Strutabout, I don't doubt, will vote for Mr. Worthy and Mr. Wou'dbe.

sp.speaker: Twiſt.
sp.p: Yes, that I will: what could I do better?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Aye, ſo will we all.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Gentlemen, for your forwardneſs in favour of my good friend Worthy, my ſincere thanks are but a poor expreſſion in the pleaſure I feel. For my part, your eſteem I ſhall always attribute more to his than my own deſert. But come, let us ſit down to breakfaſt, all is ready, I believe; and you're heartily welcome to batchelors quarters. (they all ſit down to the table, he aſks each of the company which they prefer, coffee, tea, or chocolate, and each chooſes to his liking; he pours out, and the ſervants carry it around.)

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: Gentlemen, will any of you have a part of this fine ſalt ſhad? (they anſwer, yes, if you pleaſe; and he helps them.)

sp.speaker: Capt. P.
sp.p: This warm toaſt and butter is very fine, and the ſhad gives it an excellent flavour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Julip.
sp.p: Boy, give me the ſpirit. This chocolate, me thinks, wants a little lacing to make it admirable. (the ſervants bring it.)

sp.speaker: Prize.
sp.p: Mr. Wou'db • do your fiſhing places ſucceed well this year?

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Better than they've been known for ſome ſeaſons.

sp.speaker: Stern.
sp.p: I'm very glad of it: for then I can get my ſupply from you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Julip.
sp.p: Neighbour Stalk, how do crops ſtand with you?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: Indifferently well, I thank you; how are you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Julip.
sp.p: Oh, very well! we crop it gloriouſly.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: You have not breakfaſted yet, neighbour, give me leave to help you to another diſh.

sp.speaker: 2d Freeholder.
sp.p: Thank ye, ſir, but enough's as good as a feaſt.

sp.speaker: Capt. P.
sp.p: (looking ai his watch.) I'm afraid we ſhall be late, they ought to have begun before now.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: Our horſes are at the gate, and we have not far to go.

sp.speaker: Freeholders all.
sp.p: Very well, we've all breakfaſted. (they riſe from table, and the ſervants take away.)

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: Come along, my friends, I long to ſee your triumph. Huzza for Wou'dbe and Worthy! Exit huzzaing.

div.head: SCENE IV. The court-houſe yard.
div.stage: The door open, and a number of freeholders ſeen crouding within.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: (to a freeholder coming out of the houſe) How do votes go, neighbour? for Wou'dbe and Worthy?

sp.speaker: 2d Freeholder.
sp.p: Aye, aye, they're juſt come, and ſit upon the bench, and yet all the votes are for them. 'Tis quite a hollow thing. The poll will be ſoon over. The People croud ſo much, and vote ſo faſt, you can hardly turn round.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: How do Strutabout and Smallhopes look? very doleful, I reckon.

sp.speaker: 2d Freeholder.
sp.p: Like a thief under the gallows.

sp.speaker: 3d Freeholder.
sp.p: There you muſt be miſtaken, neighbour: for two can't be like one.

sp.speaker: 1ſt & 2d Freeholders.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—a good joke, a good joke.

sp.speaker: 3d Freeholder.
sp.p: Not ſo good neither, when the ſubject ma • e it ſo eaſy.

sp.speaker: 1ſt & 2d Freeholders.
sp.p: Better and better, ha, ha, ha. Huzza for Worthy and Wou'dbe! and confuſion to Strutabout and Smallhopes.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Huzza for Wou'dbe and Worthy! and huzza for • ir John Toddy! tho' he reclines.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: So Guzzle, your good friend Sir John reclines, does he? I think he does right.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: You think he does right! pray ſir, what right have you to think about it? nobody but a fool would kick a fallen man lower.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: Sir, I won't be called a fool by any man, I'll have you to know, ſir.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Then you ought'nt to be one; but here's at ye, adrat ye, if ye're for a quarrel. Sir John Toddy would have ſtood a good chance, and I'll maintain it, come on, damn ye.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Freeholder.
sp.p: On! as for fighting, there I'm your ſervant; a drunkard is as bad to fight as a madman. (runs off.)

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: Houroa, houroa, you ſee no body ſo good at a battle as a ſtaunch toper. The milkſops are afraid of them to a man.

sp.speaker: 3d Freeholder.
sp.p: You knew he was a coward before you thought proper to attack him; if you think yourſelf ſo brave, try your hand upon me, and you'll find you're miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Guzzle.
sp.p: For the matter of that, I'm the beſt judge myſelf; good day, my dear, good day. Huzza, for Sir John Toddy. Exit.

sp.speaker: 3d Freeholder.
sp.p: How weak muſt Sir John be to be governed by ſuch a wretch as Guzzle! The Sheriff comes to the door, and ſays, Gentlemen freeholders, come into court, and give your votes, or the poll will be cloſed.

sp.speaker: Freeholders.
sp.p: We've all voted.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.p: The poll's cloſed. Mr. Wou'dbe and Mr. Worthy are elected.

sp.speaker: Freeholders without and within.
sp.p: Huzza—huzza! Wou'dbe and Worthy for ever, boys, bring 'em on, bring 'em on, Wou'dbe and Worthy for ever!

div.stage: Enter Wou'dbe and Worthy, in two chairs, raiſed aloft by the freeholders.

sp.speaker: Freeholders all.
sp.p: —Huzza, for Wou'be and Worthy—Huzza for Wou'dbe and Worthy—huzza, for Wou'dbe and Worthy!— (they traverſe the ſtage, and then ſet them down.)

sp.speaker: Worthy.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I'm much obliged to you for the ſignal proof you have given me to-day of your regard. You may depend upon it, that I ſhall endeavour faithfully to diſcharge the truſt you have repoſed in me.

sp.speaker: Wou'dbe.
sp.p: I have not only, gentlemen, to return you my hearty thanks for the favours you have conferred upon me, but I beg leave alſo to thank you for ſhewing ſuch regard to the merit of my friend. You have in that, ſhewn your judgment, and a ſpirit of independence becoming Virginians.

sp.speaker: Capt P.
sp.p: So we have Mr. Wou'dbe, we have done as we ought, we have elected the ableſt, according to the writ.

lg.l: Henceforth, let thoſe who pray for wholeſome laws,
And all well-wiſhers to their country's cauſe,
Like us refuſe a coxcomb—chooſe a man—
Then let our ſenate blunder if it can.

div.p: THE PATRIOTS, A COMEDY, IN FIVE ACTS.

list.head: Two gentlemen of fortune accuſed of toryiſm.

list.item: M'Flint, M'Squeeze and M'Gripe, three Scotchmen.
Mr. Tackabout, a pretended whig, and real tory.
Mira, daughter to Brazen, in love with Trueman.
Butler, Cook, Scullion and a Servant to Meanwell.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: MR. Trueman, I am happy to ſee you. In times like theſe, of war and danger, almoſt every man is ſuſpicious even of his friend; but with you I may converſe with the utmoſt confidence.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: My dear Meanwell, I know your heart, and am ſorry that any man can ſuſpect its purity; but our caſe is much the ſame.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: What? are you too accuſed of toryiſm?

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: I am indeed. Unfortunately, I have ſome enemies who have raiſed the cry againſt me. And what is worſe, I fear the conſequences will be ſerious, and a little uncommon.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p:
They will be bad indeed if they cauſe the loſs of the girl I love. To your friendly boſom I may truſt the ſecrets of my heart. The lovely Mira, daughter of our old neighbour Brazen has won my affections. You know her beauteous form; but that is but an image of her ſoul, its more charming inhabitant. I had ſeen and loved her: her father declared his approbation of my paſſion, and encouraged me to proceed. Heaven ſeemed to promiſe me ſucceſs, and the idol of my ſoul had with bluſhing tenderneſs conſented
to be my bride. But all our hopes may probably be blaſted by this unfortunate circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: It cannot be doubted. Her father is a violent patriot without knowing the meaning of the word. He underſtands little or nothing beyond a dice-box and race-field, but thinks he knows every thing; and woe be to him that contradicts him! His political notions are a ſyſtem of perfect anarchy, but he reigns in his own family with perfect deſpotiſm. He is fully reſolved that nobody ſhall tyrannize over him, but very content to tyrannize over others. I happened in converſation to oppoſe ſome of his doctines of a ſtate of nature and liberty without reſtraint, and he blazed out immediately like a flaſh of gunpowder. I endeavored to moderate his anger; but as reaſon and he can never be reconciled, I am afraid my ſins will never be forgiven; beſides, I have a bitter enemy and rival in Captain Flaſh.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Ay, that is the drawcanſir of modern times; a fellow who pretends to cat the ſmoke of a cannon freſh from the mouth, and to kill all the enemies of his country, as Caligula would the Roman people, at one blow. But I believe he's a coward at bottom.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p:
So do I. But Old Brazen is perſuaded that not even Waſhington is his parallel. As I pretend not to extravagant valour, the captain thinks me a puny milkſop, and judges it very great preſumption in me to pretend to the lady he adores. I expect he has aſſiſted the old man's prepoſſeſſion againſt me; and, by his aſſertions, convinced him I am a tory:— But this is certain, the old gentleman declared that I
ſhould never enter his doors with his conſent again, and moreover has commanded his daughter to think no more of having me for her huſband.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: What a pity it is that all heads are not capable of receiving the benign influence of the principles of liberty—ſome are too weak to bear it, and become thoroughly intoxicated. The cauſe of my country appears as dear to me as to thoſe who moſt paſſionately declaim on the ſubject. The rays of the ſun of freedom, which is now riſing, have warmed my heart; but I hope my zeal againſt tyranny will not be ſhewn by bawling againſt it, but by ſerving my country againſt her enemies; and never may I ſignalize my attachment to liberty by perſecuting innocent men, only becauſe they differ in opinion with me.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: It ſeems for this very reaſon you are not accounted a patriot; but truth will at laſt prevail, the faithful heart be applauded, and the noiſy hypocrite ſtripped of the maſk of patriotiſm.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I hope ſo; and therefore truth, plain truth, ſhall be the only ſhield I will uſe againſt my foes. Men who aim at power without merit, muſt conceal the meanneſs of their ſouls by noiſy and paſſionate ſpeeches in favour of every thing which is the current opinion of the day; but real patriots are mild, and ſecretly anxious for their country, but modeſt in expreſſions of zeal. They are induſtrious in the public ſervice, but claim no glory to themſelves.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p:
May the armies of America be always led by ſuch as theſe! Thus will the power of Britain be
overthrown, and peace with liberty return—May men like theſe conduct our government, and happineſs, in the train of independence, will bleſs the ſmiling land! But before this can be accompliſhed many temporary evils muſt be ſupported with patience.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Yes, and this under which we now labour among the reſt. But what do you propoſe to do in the caſe of your lovely Mira? you won't give up the purſuit?

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Give up the purſuit? When I do, may I be hanged as a traitor to love! But it ſeems a little difficult at preſent. I have taken the liberty to uſe your ſervant already in the buſineſs. As he very lately came into this part of the country, and poſſeſſes a very genteel air, I thought he might eaſily paſs for a gentleman with old Brazen. I equip'd him therefore as an officer, and ſent him to the houſe of the old gentleman; and ordered him to paſs himſelf for a travelling captain, and to wait for an opportunity of delivering a letter to Mira. He executed the commiſſion with fidelity, and brought me an anſwer from her, in which ſhe communicates to me all that I have told you.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: And what do you intend to do?

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: With your permiſſion I'll make uſe of your ſervant upon a ſecond embaſſy.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: By all means; but what do you propoſe?

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: In the purſuit of honorable love few things are reprehenſible. I ſhall intreat her to elope with me into a neighbouring government, where Hymen ſhall make us one.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: All fair, in my opinion; as you had her father's licence to win her affections, you have an undoubted right to her perſon.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: I am happy you do not condemn my plan.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I will be of your party, your aid-de-camp in this affair. Your ambaſſador ſhall wait on you immediately. In love and war no time ſhould be loſt.

div.head: SCENE II. A drawing-room.
div.l: The conſtant dove on yonder ſpray,
Cooing, tunes a moving lay;
She warbles out a tender note,
And fills with love her little throat.
No anxious doubts annoy her breaſt:
Her mate, the guardian of her neſt,
Her pretty young attends with care,
And frees her mind from ev'ry fear.
So the maid, that's join'd to thee,
My lovely Trueman, bleſt would be.
Thy virtues would attune her breaſt.
To conſtant eaſe, to perfect reſt.
div.p: Oh, Trueman! nothing but the fear of loſing you, gives me pain. Poſſeſſed of thee, I could join the lark to welcome in the roſy morn, and ſing with Philomel the moon to reſt.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: How d'ye do Mira? Mercy child, how grave you look? Come, I'll ſing you a catch of the new ſong, that will inſpire you, I'm ſure.

lg.l: As Colinet and Phoebe ſat,
Beneath a poplar grove;
With fondeſt truth tne gentle youth,
Was telling tales of love.

sp.p: There's a ſong for you.—

lg.l: But ah! is this a time for bliſs,
Or themes ſo ſoft as theſe?
While all around, we hear no ſound
But war's terrific ſtrain,
The drum commands our arming bands,
And chides each tardy ſwain.
My love ſhall crown the youth alone,
Who ſaves himſelf and me—

sp.p: What a noble thought is this, my dear Mira! I am determined never to marry any man that has not fought a battle.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Your ſwain then muſt have a hard courtſhip. But ſuppoſe he ſhould happen to be killed?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Why then, I ſhould never marry him, you know. But I am reſolved not to love a man who knows nothing of war and Waſhington. War and Waſhington! don't you think thoſe words have a noble ſound?

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: They have indeed; and I acknowledge the ſmiles of beauty ſhould reward the man who bravely aſſerts his country's rights, and meets her enemies in the bloody field; but do you love war for its own ſake?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Lord, no, but then there's ſomething ſo clever in fighting and dying for one's country; and the officers look ſo clever and ſmart; I declare I never ſaw an ugly officer in my life.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p:
Your fancy muſt be a great beautifier, as
many of them are not much indebted to nature for perſonal charms.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Ay, that's becauſe you are not in love with an officer. When you are, you'll think as I do.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Are you in love with one?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Ah! now that's an ill-natured queſtion, I tell you, child, I am in love with nothing but my country. If, indeed, a man ſhould approach me, who would lay his laurels at my feet, who could count his glorious fears gained in the front of victory, I might look upon him.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe, then, if he wanted an arm, a leg or an eye, it would be all the better; or a great cut over his eye-brow, would be a beauty ſpot.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Certainly. Nothing can be more elegant. It appears ſo martial—ſo—ſo—quite the thing.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Well! I'm afraid my taſte will never be quite ſo grand as your's, tho' I hope I love my country as well as you.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: You love your country! your ſentiments are not refined enough: they are not exalted to the level of patriotiſm; for my part, I ſcorn to think of any thing elſe.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Well, but my dear, don't you think the politicians are capable of ſettling theſe matters better than you or me?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: The politicians! and who are ſuch politicians as the women? We fairly beat the men, it is univerſally acknowledged. And why may not I have talents that way? who knows but I may be a general's lady, or wife to a member of Congreſs, ſome of theſe days?

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: I heartily wiſh you may; but would it not be better not to loſe time in thinking about things ſo remote, and attend more to thoſe of the preſent moment?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Remote, indeed! not ſo very remote, I hope! The times are very buſy, and great men very plentiful, and no body can tell what will happen. But, my dear, I can't ſtay any longer. I ſent my ſervant for the news-papers, and expect he is come by this time. So, child, I wiſh you a good day, and a good huſband ſoon, tho' you don't aſpire to marry a general! Exit.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: That poor girl's head is turned topſy turvy by the little inſignificant animal that dangles about her: ſhe has converſed with him, till ſhe has not only adopted his opinions, but caught his ideas. Oh! Trueman, what a difference!

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: What damn'd buſineſs employs your thoughts, Mira? you are always in a ſtudy.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: My principal ſtudy, ſir, is to pleaſe my father.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: That's clever, my girl. I'll tell you, Mira, I intend to marry you to my friend the captain.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: What captain, ſir? There are ſo many captains now-a-days, that I might gueſs a fortnight before I hit upon the man, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Captain Flaſh, is the man. He's the man, Mira, a fellow of mettle, ſpirited to the back-bone. He'll fight for his country: thoſe are the men, girl.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Has he ever been in a battle, ſir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: He's in the army, child, that's enough.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Shou'd I not ſee him, ſir, before I promiſe to accept him?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: See him! yes, and feel him too, for what I care; he's a damn'd fine fellow, a fellow of ſpirit. If you like him, take him; if not, let him alone. I don't care who you take, ſo he's no tory, d—m all tory's, ſay I. Exit.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.p: That was aim'd at Trueman; who will ever be ſuſpected, as long as falſe patriots and pretenders to heroiſm have my father's ear. Well, as an obedient daughter, I will endure one tete-a-tete with this fine fellow he recommends. Mercy on me, here he comes!

div.head: SCENE VII. To her, Flaſh ſinging.
div.l: Lift up your heads, ye heroes,
And ſwear with proud diſdain
The wretch that wou'd enſlave us,
Shall ſpread his ſnares in vain.
We'll blaſt the venal ſycophants,
Who dare our rights betray.
Huzza! Huzza! Huzza! Huzza!
My brave America.
div.p: Noble, by God! d—m me! here's the ſtuff, (drawing his ſword) ſhall make the cowardly dogs ſkip, we'll let the ſcoundrels ſee what Americans can do; ha! Miſs, your moſt humble—do you know that I have a vaſt propenſity to quit the army for your ſake?

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: For ſhame, ſir, what! deſert the ſervice of your country, when ſhe moſt ſtands in need of your aſſiſtance?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Why really, madam, I ſhould be damnably miſs'd. Upon my ſoul I don't know what they wou'd do without me.
