sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Then by no means quit the ſervice, captain.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: By God I think I have ſerved long enough. Others ſhould try their luck as well as I: for a whole year have I been fighting, thro' heat and cold, wet and dry, hunger and thirſt; poor Flaſh! were you not a heart of oak, a compound of ſteel and gun-flints, you cou'd not ſtand it, by heavens! here's he that fears nothing. (ſings.)

lg.l: Shou'd Europe empty all her force,
We'll meet her in array,
And ſhout and fight, and ſhout and fight,
My brave America.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Bravo, captain!

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Mars, I adore thee; Mars, was a fellow of ſpirit, I'm told, the Flaſh of his day, I warrant it. By God, I wiſh the lad was here now, that he and I might have a game at tilts together: (draws his ſword and puſhes at the wall.) Ha, ha; there I had him! I'god, now I cou'd gizzard theſe Engliſh dogs, if I had 'em here.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Pray, captain, put up your ſword, I declare you frighten me.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Frighen you! 'Sblood, madam, the ladies now-a-days ſhould be all amazons, nothing ſhou'd pleaſe them more than a naked ſword: however, to pleaſe you, up love (puts up his ſword.) entre nous, d'ye ſee, Miſs, I do think you are a deviliſh fine girl. Your father, ma'am, has given me leave.—

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Fie, captain.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: By my ſoul, he has.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: For ſhame, ſir, a ſoldier talk at this rate! fighting ſhou'd be your theme, captain.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Fighting! 'tis victuals and drink to me. I could breakfaſt upon fighting, dine and ſup upon fighting; but after ſupper, a fine girl, you know—

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: War and love can never go hand in hand. Love enervates the ſoul, and wou'd make the braveſt man upon earth a coward.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Coward: (draws his ſword) Coward! damn the word, how it makes my blood boil.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.p: Coward! ha! If you had not been a woman, well, (puts up his ſword.) 'Tis no matter, but I'll be damn'd, if ever I ſpeak to you again. Exit.

div.head: SCENE IX. Melinda, and Pickle dreſſed like an officer, croſſing the ſtage, meeting each other.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Here am I forced to walk three miles to warp a piece of cloth. Mammy ſays I was born for a fine lady, but I am ſure this does not look like it.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: (ſeeing her) Ha, a beautiful creature, by my ſoul! artleſs and innocent no doubt. (I'll try my luck with her by God) let me ſee (muſing) I'll take her in the old way, I believe; addreſs her in heroics, talk of my honourabl • intentions, and promiſe marriage. Come to my aſſiſtance, dear cunning, and ſweet diſſimulation; ye tru harbingers of luſt and love.— Sweet Miſs, your moſt humble.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Miſs! Lord, how charming that is.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Charming girl! By God, I'm at a loſs how to begin. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: (looking at his hat.) what a pretty feather! are you in the wars, ſir?

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: I have ſerved ſeveral campaigns, Miſs, (under the banners of Venus) (aſide) I have been in many engagements.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I hope you never got hurt, ſir.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: A trifling ſcratch or two is all the injury I ever received.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Do you intend to continue a ſoldier?

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Nothing but a wife ſhall ever induce me to quit the ſervice.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Do you intend to marry, ſir?

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: As ſoon as I can get any one in the humour to have me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Any one would not do, I gueſs: you'll chooſe ſome rich lady, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: No, Miſs, riches are not my object; I have a ſufficient fortune of my own, thank God; I would marry a woman without a ſhilling, if ſhe hit my taſte, ſuch a ſweet angel as yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Thank you, ſir, for your fleers.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: As I hope for ſalvation, I would rather have you (for a time, aſide) than any woman I ever ſaw.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: 'Tis not worth your while to make your fun of a poor girl.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Fun! upon my ſoul I'm in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: A gentleman like you wou'd never marry a poor girl, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: There, Miſs, you are miſtaken: I had rather marry a poor girl than a rich one. My reaſons are the beſt in the world: a poor girl wou'd think herſelf obliged to me, wou'd love me from gratitude, and make me an induſtrious, frugal, good wife; a rich one would think ſhe obliged me, and would want a thouſand things, a fine houſe, fine ſervants, fine clothes, a fine equipage, all her requeſts to be granted, and never to be contradicted in any thing: If I marry a poor girl, I get a wife; if a rich one, I get a miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You don't mean what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: I do upon my ſoul, my intentions are honourable; your name, my dear.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Melinda Heartfree, ſir.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Well, my dear, it ſhall be Mrs. Meanwell, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Is your name Meanwell, ſir?

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: It is, madam. No doubt you have often heard of me, perhaps ſeen me before: my name and character will remove any ſuſpicion you may entertain of my integrity and honour, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I have often heard daddy talk of you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: What is your father's opinion of me, Miſs?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: He likes you mightily, and ſo does mammy too; you ſtood for ſiſter Bibby, when you ſet up for • urgeſs.

True, my dear, I well remember it: and are yo •
〈◊〉 daughter of my old friend Heartfree? Come to 〈◊〉
• s, (embraces her) my dear girl, I ſhall
be proud to be ſon-in-law to a man of his worth and goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You ſurely are not in earneſt, ſir!

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: I am, and to convince you of my ſincerity, I would immediately wait upon you home, and communicate my intentions to your friends; but I have ſome buſineſs to-day that prevents me: however, I ſhall be this way to-morrow; will my dear girl be ſo kind as to meet me?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: There is no harm in coming here, ſir: I can do it to oblige you; but you will forget me, and every thing you have ſaid to me, before to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Impoſſible that I •• n ever forget that ſweet face! (he kiſſes her, ſhe ſeems coy) will you meet me here about twelve o'clock, to-morrow? Don't be cruel, my ſweet girl; you know I love you: my words, my looks, my actions muſt diſcover it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Well, ſir, I'll be a fool for once, I'll come.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Charming creature, one kiſs my love (kiſſes her) 'tis ecſtacy by heavens! (Exit Melinda) Well! theſe ignorant girls are the fineſt game in the world: heave a ſigh, look languiſhingly, and ſwear a little, the poor things drop their heads into your boſom, and die away as quick as a ſenſitive plant. Well, Trueman, having plann'd a ſcheme of amuſement for myſelf, I'll now proceed to the execution of your commands. Exit.

div.head: SCENE I. A court-houſe.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: What, is the committee to meet to-day, Meanwell? I hate theſe little democracies.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Take care, ſir, both property and characters lie at the mercy of thoſe tribunals.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: What weighty buſineſs calls their high mightineſſes together?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Moſt of the Caledonians are ſuſpected of diſaffection to the American cauſe, and either from friendſhip or attachment to their own country, diſapprove the public meaſures: from this cauſe, our holy inquiſition are for the very moderate correction the Jews received in Spain.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Baniſhment, or a renunciation of their error, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: This may be the cauſe; at preſent an oath is to be applied as a mirror to their breaſts, which reflecting their private opinions and ſentiments, muſt lay them open to the public eye. This is to be offered as a touch-ſtone of public virtue, as a trial of faith; and woe be unto thoſe who are found faithleſs.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: The ungracious treatment that ſome Scotchmen have met with, the illiberal reflections caſt out againſt them all, give little hope of their attachment to a country, or to a people, where and with whom they have already taſted the bitter herb of perſecution: ſome there are, who have behaved well, conform'd to the public will, nor given any cauſe of offence; yet even thoſe have not met with the common offices of civility among us.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Of this character are thoſe who are cited before the committee to-day.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Huſh, ſir, here come two of the guardians of our ſtate.

div.stage: Enter Col. Strut and Mr. Summons.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: We delegates, Mr. Summons, have a very hard time of it.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Men of abilities muſt give themſelves up to the ſervice of their country.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: True, ſir, the people will exact the ſervices of thoſe they can depend upon.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Your wiſe men, as they call them, cut but a poor figure in theſe times.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: They are dangerous men: they are always ſtarting doubts and creating diviſions; diviſions are dangerous. United we ſtand, divided we fall, is the American motto, you know.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Very true Colonel, very true. When I became a delegate, I was told it was the ready way to ſome profitable poſt. I long to ſerve my country.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Enter into the army, ſir; that is the way to preferment.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I am a cripple, and can't be a ſoldier.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Be a colonel of militia then, 'tis a fine poſt for cripples, for they never march, but they have no pay, Mr. Summons: you want a poſt that will bring you ſomething.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: I love my country and wiſh to ſerve her, and I wiſh ſome folks were as true to their country as they ought to be.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p:
And as diſintereſted too, and then men of
real merit, would be in her ſervice, in lieu of them who get into office, to catch a few ſixpences from her treaſury.

div.stage: Enter Brazen, Thunderbelt, Squib and Skip.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: How goes it? How goes it? Well, what buſineſs do we meet upon to-day?

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: The Scabbies are to be tried according to the ordinance.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Let's duck the ſcoundrels.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: Duck 'em! let's burn the ſcoundrels.

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: Let's hang them.

sp.speaker: Squib.
sp.p: Ay, ay, hang them, that is the beſt way.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: How goes it, old cock?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why, praiſe be to God, thro' mercy, I'm reaſonably well, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I underſtand thoſe gentlemen take part with the Scotch (pointing to Trueman and Meanwell.)

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: It is a common talk.

sp.speaker: Squib.
sp.p: The people don't like it.

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: Some talk very hard of it, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: If to treat the unhappy with kindneſs be an offence, I ſhall always be an offending ſinner; meanneſs dwells with oppreſſion, and cowardice with inſult.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Juſtice is the birthright of all, and public virtue is diſplayed by an impartial diſtribution of it.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Wou'd you protect our enemies, gentlemen? would you ruin your country for the ſake of Scotchmen?

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Prove them to be enemies, ſhew that they plot the downfall of my country, and courteſy itſelf ſhall revolt againſt them.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: There is ſufficient proof that nine hundred and ninety-nine out of a thouſand of them are our enemie.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Some may be enemies, others guiltleſs. 'Tis ungenerous to arraign this man for the offence of his neighbour; illiberal to traduce all for the tranſgreſſions of a few.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Juſtice would bluſh at ſuch proceedings: Pity, drop a tear at the outrage.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Here comes the Scotchmen.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Gentlemen of the committee, pray take your ſeats (they ſit round a table.) I was requeſted by colonel Strut, to ſummon theſe men here (coughs) I have a bad cold, tell me, if you pleaſe colonel, what it is about.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: (riſing) Theſe men, gentlemen, are cited before this committee, agreeable to an ordinance of convention.

sp.speaker: M'Flint.
sp.p: What is our offence, pray?

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: The nature of their offence, gentlemen, is, that they are Scotchmen; every Scotchman being an enemy, and theſe men being Scotchmen, they come under the ordinance which directs an oath to be tendered to all thoſe againſt whom there is juſt cauſe to ſuſpect they are enemies.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: (riſing) As theſe men are Scotchmen, I think there is juſt cauſe to ſuſpect that they are our enemies. Let it be put to the committee, Mr. preſident, whether all Scotchmen are not enemies.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: A good notion, Mr. Brazen, I ſecond it with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: We have ſome Scotchmen in our army; they are our friends, I hope.

sp.speaker: Squib.
sp.p: To be ſartin they muſt be our friends.

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: Yes, yes, they are our friends, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: They are excepted of courſe.

sp.speaker: M'Squeeze.
sp.p: I wiſh the country very well, I never did it harm, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: M'Gripe.
sp.p: I've gi'en nae cauſe to ſuſpect that I am an enemy. The ordinance ſays, ye muſt hae juſt cauſe. Bring your proof, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Proof, ſir! we have proof enough. We ſuſpect any Scotchman: ſuſpicion is proof, ſir. I move for the queſtion, Mr. Preſident.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: In the catalogue of ſins, I never found it one before to be born on the north of the Tweed. (aſide to Mean.)

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: In nature's loweſt works, I never ſaw before ſuch baſe ſtupidity. (aſide to True.)

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: The queſtion, Mr. Preſident.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The queſtion, the queſtion.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Is all Scotchmen enemies, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay, ay.

sp.speaker: M'Flint.
sp.p: Before you determine ſo precipitately, gentlemen, I ſhould have been glad to ſay ſomewhat in my own defence.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: What is it, my dear ſir?

sp.speaker: M'Flint.
sp.p: I was bred in Scotland, but not born there.

sp.speaker: M'Squeeze.
sp.p: What, Sandy, do you deny your country mon, tak ſhame to yourſel, Sandy.

sp.speaker: M'Flint.
sp.p: It is time to deny man, when they make it a crime to be born there.

sp.speaker: M'Gripe.
sp.p: I'll loſe my life for dear old Scotland, before ev • I'll bluſh for it.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p:
As Mr. M'Flint ſays he's no Scotchman, we have no •
〈◊〉 to ſuſpect him more than any other man.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: A • he's no Scotchman, he may be a very good man▪ I move that he be diſcharged.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: I riſe to move, ſir, (coughs) I ſay, ſir, I move that the oath be tender'd to theſe men, according to the ordinance.

sp.speaker: M'Squeeze.
sp.p: What oath?

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: The teſt oath, ſir; you muſt ſwear to be true and faithful to this country.

sp.speaker: M'Squeeze.
sp.p: I'll take nae oath, the like o' that.

sp.speaker: M'Gripe.
sp.p: I'll no ſwear allegiance to any man but my king.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: There, gentleman, you ſee what they are, they are all ſo to a man.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I move that they be diſarmed, as the ordidinance directs.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, the buſineſs is done; I ſuppoſe we may riſe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay, ay. They riſe.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Is the committee up? I'm ſorry I was not here a little ſ •• ner. I had an information or two to lay before the committee.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: We can ſit again, ſir; order the committee to ſit again, Mr. Preſident.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Upon ſecond thoughts, we'll decline it for the preſent: I have not all the proofs about me; beſides a witneſs I expected, is not here, I find.

sp.speaker: Squib.
sp.p: I'll lay he has found out ſome tory.

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: He has got ſome tory in the wind, depend upon it.

sp.speaker: Squib.
sp.p: I declare he is the prettieſt ſpokeneſt man I ever ſaw.

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: Yes, between you and me, he ought to have been our delegate.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Well, gentlemen, you have trounced thoſe Scotch gentlemen, I hope.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: We have.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: So, colonel, you have reſigned your commiſſion, I'm told. (to col. Simple.)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Yes, my friend; I grow old and infirm: I thought it beſt to decline in time.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: There's ſome prudence in retreating from danger: the times are perilous, colonel.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Young men, like you, Mr. Tackabout, are the propereſt perſons for commiſſions: ſuch old folks as I, are better out of the way.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Out of harm's way, you mean, colonel.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I think ſuch men as you ought to ſtep forth: I have often heard you boaſt of your courage, Mr. Tackabout; now's the time, ſir—now or never.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Why ſir, I have ſome expectations in England; the reverſion of a conſiderable eſtate, or—

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Poh! damn the eſtate; let it go.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: My anceſtors loſt an eſtate by their loyalty; I ſhould not chooſe to loſe mine by my diſloyalty.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſin to loſe an eſtate any how; that's certain.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: A man's patrimony, in my opinion, is a ſacred depoſitum, eſpecially when an expected title gives luſtre to the poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Damn the title—take a commiſſion: that's better than all the titles in the world.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Take my commiſſion, Mr. Tackabout: it is expected you ſhould do ſomething, indeed it is.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: I have done enough already, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: But I obſerve, you keep out of harm's way, Mr. Tackabout.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Where is the man that has done more than I have? I have damn'd the miniſtry, abus'd the king, vilified the parliament, and curs'd the Scotch. I have raiſed the people's ſuſpicions againſt all moderate men; adviſed them to ſpurn at all government: I have cried down tories, cried up whigs, extolled Waſhington as a god, and call'd Howe a very devil. I have exclaimed againſt a • l taxes, adviſed the people to pay no debts; I have promiſed them ſucceſs in war, a free trade, and independent dominion. In ſhort, I have inſpired them with the true patriotic fire, the ſpirit of oppoſition; and yet you ſay it is expected I ſhould do ſomething.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: There are many to be found, who do all this.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: And few who do any thing elſe. (aſide)

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Can this be the perſon we were in company with the other day, Trueman? (aſide)

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: The very ſame, only Proteus like, he can change from a man to a brute, from a brute to a ſerpent, or to any thing he pleaſes. (to Meanwell.)

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Trueman, your ſervant; Meanwell, your's. I beg pardon, I really did not obſerve you were preſent.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: We ſhould not have been offended if you had overlooked us altogether, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Poh. Never mind what I ſay to theſe fellows, you know my private ſentiments.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: As well as they do, I ſuppoſe, Mr. Tackabout; but, ſir, the man who privately condemns, and publicly approves either men or meaſures, ſh • ws himſelf a knave, and proves himſelf a coward. (aſide to Tackabout.)

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Come, ſir, no more, ſir, I beg of you; I talk to theſe fellows always in their own ſtyle, to avoid ſuſpicion; nothing elſe, upon ••• our, ſir, (aſide to Trueman.)

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: So, ſir, you inculcate principles ſubverſive of every public and private virtue, you encourage oppreſſion and ſpread ſedition, merely for your own ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Prudence requires ſomething of this kind.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: What you call prudence, I call baſeneſs, Mr. Tackabout: however, I leave you to the pleaſures of your prudent duplicity—Meanwell, I wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I'll attend you, ſir. Exit Mean, and True.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: You and the tories were at croſs-queſtions, I believe, Mr. Tackabout.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: It is always the caſe, ſir: I wiſh to reclaim the fellows, and cannot but repeat a little of my political catechiſm to them whenever we meet.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: 'Tis a pity ſuch clever men ſhould be enemies to their country.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: They are dangerous men; ſhew me a clever man, and I'll ſhew you an enemy; let me adviſe you to keep a ſtrict eye upon thoſe men. Mr. Preſident.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: D—mn all tories, ſay I. Come, let us go into the muſter-ground. Exit omnes.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: (holding a news-paper in his hand) ha! damn me, I thought ſo; yes, yes, honies, you have got it, nine hundred at a clip. Well done, Waſhington, by God! We'll trim the raſcals, d—me.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: What's that, captain?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Great, very great; we have done it at laſt.

sp.speaker: Squib.
sp.p: What have we done, captain?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Every thing, by God; a noble ſtroke, old fellow; we have killed and taken nine hundred of the damned infidels.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: Read it, captain, read it.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Poh! damn it, you know I hate reading; can't you believe me? there it is, in black and white.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: (reads) "A copy of his excellency general Waſhington's letter to congreſſ, dated, Trenton."

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: That's it; d—n my buttons, if I would not give a million that I had been there.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: This is great news, really, captain.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p:
It will do; but it might have been better, and more complete. Some got off, you ſee; if I had been there, I'll be damn'd if a ſingle ſcoundrel ſhould
have eſcaped; and here am I doing nothing, but encouraging a ſet of poltroons to enter into the ſervice; ever perplexed, vexed, and diſappointed—not a breath of applauſe; not a ſprig of laurel for poor Flaſh, while others are reaping it by handfuls.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: Never mind, captain, it will be your time, ſoon.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Soon! The enemy will be driven to the de. vil, before I ſhall arrive at the ſcene of action.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Noble captain, your ſervant—we ſhall ſoon get our complement of men; there are ſeveral ſine fellows that intend to liſt.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Noble fellows: have you any thing for them to drink.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: I have the recruiting jugs full to the brim.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Peach brandy, the beſt liquor in the world.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Produce it, d—me, and give the lads a drink.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Never mind me; never mind me, captain, I'll do it.
sp.l: Come on my brave fellows, a fig for our lives,
We'll fight for our country, our children and wives;
Determin'd we are to live happy and free,
Then join honeſt fellows, in chorus with me.
A fig for the Engliſh—they may buſs all our breeches.
Thoſe bloodſucking, beer-drinking puppies retreat,
But our peach-brandy fellows can never be beat.
sp.p: Where's the ſpring?

sp.speaker: Mob.
sp.p: We'll ſhew it you.

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Come on, my brave fellows.

sp.speaker: Mob.
sp.p: Huzza! for the noble ſerjeant. Exit ſhouting.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: My ſerjeant has enliſted ſeveral fine fellows for me; but perſecuted with the wheedling of wives, or the entreaties of parents, I am obliged to diſcharge the cowards as faſt as I get them.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: You ſhould not let your good nature prejudice the ſervice, captain.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Prejudice the ſervice! D—me, ſir, I don't know what you mean.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: I beg pardon—I only meant to ſay, you ought not to be too good-natured.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: D—n good nature, ſir, I ſcorn it. If I let a man off, 'tis for his money; he pays for his peeping, honey.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: That's right; it makes the more bounty-money for others.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: No, no, thank you, none of that, my dear; where are my expences to come from, do you think?

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: I thought the public allowed for theſe.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: The public allowance is nothing, if it was not for a little ſmart-money, and now and then a run of luck, I ſhould abſolutely periſh.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: Do you ever play at cards?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: A pretty queſtion, d—me! Why gaming and whoring are the two firſt qualifications of a ſoldier.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: What ſay you to a crack at all-fours, now?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: Let us go into yonder houſe, and ſet to it like brave fellows: my lieutenant ſhall play with you for what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Here's he that never flinches. Enter Trim. Well, Trim, what luck?

sp.speaker: Trim.
sp.p: Why, ſir, I got ten clever fellows to promiſe me to enliſt (hickups) do you ſee me, juſt as the brandy gave out, they kept punctually calling for more grog, I told them, ſays I, (hickups) I am very ſorry, ſays I, the brandy is out. e'god, ſir, the words were no ſooner out of my mouth, (hickups) than away they went, every ſoul of them.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: I am glad of it, for I may perhaps find another uſe for the bounty-money. Trim meet me at old Brazen's to-night. Come, gentlemen. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: Prithee, Mira, lay aſide thoſe demure looks; when every creature is running mad for joy at the glorious news from the northward, here are you like an Egyptian mummy—without ſenſe or motion.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: I have a fit of the horrors, Miſs, whenever I hear of a battle.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: So have I, if it goes againſt us.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Victory is attended with the widows lamentations, and the orphan's tears; I cannot rejoice at any thing, that ſounds with funeral dirges, or makes joy ſmile in the face of affliction.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Were I a lump of clay, or an image of wax, the word victory would make me ſpring into life, and ſing Te deum.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: The untimely death of a parent, huſband, or child, might prevent your vivacity, Miſs.

sp.speaker: Iſ.
sp.p: Was I to be made a widow by every victory, I verily think I ſhould rejoice.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Parental and filial tenderneſs are too nearly allied to our natures, connubial bliſs too valuable, the ſweet affections of ſympathy and compaſſion, are too much the ornaments of the human hear, to be caſt away for the fooliſh exultations that flow from the vain triumphs of ambition.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Do you imagine that I am ſuch a blockhead as to believe the widow's lamentations, the orphan's tears have any effect upon your ſpirits, Mira? No, no, I know better.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: What do you know, madam?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I know that a poor creature of the maſculine gender, has as high notions of connubial bliſs as your ladyſhip; that he thinks of the great duties of parental and filial tenderneſs as you do, and that he eſteems all victories horrid, unleſs they are graced with hymenial triumphs.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: You are extremely pleaſant, madam.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Poſitively, Mira, I am ſurpriſed at you.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Surpriſed at me! for what, pray?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Why, child, that you ſhould ever think of being in love with one of thoſe horrid creatures, called tories; Trueman is a ſhocking fellow.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Really, Miſs, I am as much ſurpriſed at you.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Why, child?

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: That you ſhould ever be ſimple enough to eſteem a ſilly coxcomb in politics, who puts on the name of patriot, as all coxcombs do their clothes, to be diſtinguiſhed, and to be laughed at.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: What do you mean, madam?

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: My meaning requires no interpretation, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: If you imagine your ſatyrical ſcoffs have any effect upon me, madam, you are much miſtaken. The ſhafts of envy fall ſhort of their mark, when aimed at the well guarded, public protected principles of an honeſt whig.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Irony, is a harmleſs weapon, when pointed either at folly or meanneſs.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: You are in your own houſe, madam.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Where I ſhall always be glad to entertain you, when you are diſpoſed to treat me with decency.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: How have I tranſgreſſed?

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Trueman's merits are above the ſcandal of the times: yet, Miſs, it gives me pain to hear his name mentioned in terms of reproach.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I hate tories ſo abominably, that I cannot, for my ſoul, think of them with patience: As long, madam, as you perſiſt in your fondneſs for ſuch animals, I ſhall refrain my viſits, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Do as you pleaſe, Miſs.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Madam, your ſervant; mercy, that any creature can love a tory! Exit Iſa.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: So, I have loſt one patriotic acquaintance— here comes a male bird of the ſame ſpecies, to torment me; but I'll avoid it. Exit.
D—mn me, if I am not the moſt unlucky dog that ever cut the cards. (ſeeing Mira.) ſo, honey, are you there? Puſh off, for I'll be damn'd if I'll have any thing to ſay to you.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: How goes it, captain?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: It goes damn'd hard with me, old fellow; I'm ſick.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Sick!

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Beat to death, trimmed moſt damnably; a round hundred—nothing leſs.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: What! laſhes?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Laſhes! d—me, what a thought! no, no, here's the ſtuff, (laying his hand upon his ſword) here's the ſtuff.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: How beat, then?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: A round hundred, good continental, loſt with a militia fellow, a d—mn'd milkſop lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I'll give you ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Satisfaction, ſir!

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; the ſatisfaction that all gameſters require, a chance to win your money back.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: You meant to uſe me ill, ſir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: No, upon my honour, nothing but a joke.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: If that's all, here's my hand, I'm at you, for twenty dollars a game, if you dare?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: A match, come on. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I. A dreſſing-room.
div.l: No ſounds but drums ſhall pleaſe my ear,
Farewel, ſoft folly; love, adieu:
No grief's but heroe's griefs I'll ſhare
Nor ſigh, but Waſhington, for you.
div.p: Well, what would I give to hear of another victory! I had a horrid dream laſt night: I dream't that I ſaw the congreſs running out of Philadelphia, frighted to death; ſome barefooted, others bareheaded, that they run into a great croud, where I ſoon ſaw, as I thought, my dear little colonel, bold as a lion, calling out, to arms, arms! but I was ſurpriſed to ſee the men have clubs and ſticks, inſtead of guns; and my dear little colonel with a corn ſtalk to his ſide, inſtead of a ſword. It was a horrid dream.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Your ſervant, madam.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Colonel, I am glad to ſee you.—Do you ever mind dreams, colonel?

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Pleaſant dreams are not amiſs, madam.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Well, but bad dreams, I mean. I dream't of you laſt night.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Was that a bad dream, madam?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Very bad, I thought the congreſs were running away, and that you, without a ſword, was at the head of a number of men without arms.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Dreams are illuſions; but we have had another battle with the enemy, madam.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: When, where! how, tell me, dear colonel?

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: We attacked them at Prince-Town, and have killed, and taken priſoners, a prodigious number.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Thank God: but is it true?

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: As true as the goſpel, ma'am: 'tis in the papers.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: At Prince-town, did you ſay? where's that?

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Prince-Town, is a town, ſomewhere about —where general Howe is encamped.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Don't you long to be there, colonel? Lord! If I was a man, how fond I ſhould be of it!

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: If my affairs—

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Affairs: prithee no more of that: when do you think you will ſet off?

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: It is impoſſible for me, madam—I have ſome affairs—

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Affairs, again! every thing ſhould give way to the ſervice of your country.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: If I had the conſtitution of ſome men—

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Conſtitution! why are you ſick? poſitively, colonel, if you perſiſt in making ſuch fooliſh excuſes, I ſhall hate you.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Upon my honour, madam.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: That's in my cuſtody, ſir: you pawned it to me long ago, as a pledge for the patriotiſm and courage I have given you credit for.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: I hope you don't ſuſpect me of wanting either.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Why really, I never did, but I moſt certainly ſhall, unleſs you go into the army.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: 'Tis not neceſſary that all patriots ſhould be ſoldiers.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: 'Tis neceſſary that you ſhould be a ſoldier, tho': for, to be plain with you, colonel, I am determined to be a general's lady, or never to marry.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Poſitively, madam, the ſervice will kill me.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: You'll be killed in the ſervice, you mean: That's what you apprehend.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: I could die on the field of battle with pleaſure, madam, but, —

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: No but's, colonel, you muſt be a ſoldier, indeed you muſt.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Well, madam, if it is your deſire—but I've one favour to requeſt of you, firſt.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Any thing: what is it?

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Will you condeſcend to marry me, before I go?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: No faith, won't I: the conditions upon which I engaged myſelf to you were as follows: Firſt, you were to be a delegate, next a colonel, then a general. The material condition remains yet to be complied with, on your part; that performed, perhaps I may have no objection to give you my hand.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Suppoſe I ſhould be killed?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I ſhould cry a little, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: My dear madam, there are ſoldiers enough without me.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: You muſt be a general, or quit your pretenſions to me.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: I can apply in a neighbouring ſtate, and be made a brigadier-general, without being a ſoldier.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: No, no, you ſhall fight for your commiſſion: I'll have none of your chimney-corner generals, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Will no excuſe do?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: None, ſir. I bid you adieu for the preſent; unleſs you ſet off for the army immediately, it ſhall be for ever. Exit.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p:
The devil take this: I have vapour'd away to a pretty purpoſe, faith! By pretenſions to patriotiſm,
I became a delegate; and putting on the appearance of a man of courage, I became a colonel; all to tickle the vanity of this girl—and now, truly, I muſt expoſe my life that ſhe may be a general's lady! I can't do it: I never thought of fighting in my life. What! ſtand and be ſhot at! Indeed, Miſs, if theſe are the terms you are to ſurrender upon, you may keep your citadel forever, for me: I'm for a whole ſkin, if I do pennance in it, as an old bachelor, all my days. Exit.

div.head: SCENE a field.
div.p: Simple creature! how ſoon ſhe bluſhed her conſent to every thing I propoſed? here ſhe comes, fair as Venus, and as Dian chaſte. Enter Melinda. My deareſt girl. (kiſſes her.)

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I have turned fool, you ſee, ſir, and done as you deſired. If you were in earneſt in what you ſaid yeſterday, I ſhall always be ready to oblige you in any thing.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: A pretty forward hint, by God. (aſide) Why, do you ſee, (ſcratching his head) as to that, my dear, we'll talk it over another time. I have a few preliminary articles to propoſe to you, which if you agree to, you may name the happy day.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Why, my dear, I have ſome preparatory meaſures to take, reſpecting my friends, and a previous agreement to make with you and them.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Speak plain, if you pleaſe. I don't underſtand theſe fine words.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: I ſhould be much to blame, you know, to marry any woman without knowing whether ſhe would ſuit my purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: As to that matter, you can beſt judge: you cannot look for much breeding from a poor girl like me, without any bringing up.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: My dear, that is not my objection. I only wiſh to examine my commodity before I purchaſe. (taking her hand) I wiſh to know more of you, my dear.

sp.speaker: Melin.
sp.p: (puſhing him off) You know as much as you ſhall know, 'till you have a better right than you have at preſent.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: My deareſt girl, as we are man and wife in the face of heaven, do you ſee, you ſhould not be ſo vere ſcrupulous with me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: It will be time enough to take ſuch freedoms, ſir, when I am your wife.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Wife! mercy on us! (aſide) The liberties I wiſh to take, my dear, are licenſed freedoms. Love requires ſomething of this kind to keep itſelf alive. 'Tis as neceſſary to love as fuel is to fire. If you don't let me toy and play with you a little, by my ſoul, my love will go out.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I can't help it; but you ſhall take no immodeſt freedoms with me.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Poh! a little harmleſs play, my dear, is mere paſtime, don't be afraid. (attempts to be rude)

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You don't behave like a gentleman, ſir. I aſſure you, tho' I might, perhaps, conſent to be your wife, I never will agree to be any thing elſe.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p:
Who the devil would have thought it? (aſide)
My dear, I humbly beg your pardon. The violence of my paſſion is the cauſe of theſe tranſports. Alas! with what delight would I take you for my bride— but the objections of my friends—

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: What friends?

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: I have ſome particular friends from whom I have great expectations; and your fortune and family would be with them inſuperable objections.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: As to my fortune, and family, it is out of my power to make either of them better than they are: you had better then give over all thoughts of the match.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: No: it is impoſſible. My friends ſhall not controul me. I am reſolved upon it, and you ſhall be mine.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: But your great expectations, ſir.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Oh! as to that: I hope, in time they may be reconciled, when they find the marriage is over, and cannot be prevented. For this reaſon, I think it would be beſt not to have a public marriage. I will beg you therefore, to keep the marriage a ſecret for ſome time, 'till I can reconcile them to it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: When I am your wife, you ſhall direct me in all things.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Well, my dear, my ſervant will wait upon you at this place, about ſix in the evening, and will conduct you to a friend's houſe. I'll be there with a clergyman, and proper witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Well, ſir, if you do marry me, I will ſtudy night and day to pleaſe you, and to make you happy. In the evening, you ſay?

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Yes, my love.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: 'Till then, I wiſh you well.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Adieu. Exit Melinda. Little did I expect this reſiſtance in ſo artleſs a creature. I made as ſure of my game, as if I had caught it. However, I'll entangle my pretty linnet yet, in a net often ſet by us true ſportſmen, for theſe ſhy birds. Our butler ſhall be the parſon, the cook and ſcullion the witneſſes. The butler has a moſt demure ſanctified face, and will make a tolerable good prieſt. E'gad, the idea of what is to follow, gives me a palpitation at the heart already. Well, Trueman, your buſineſs: then my own. Exit.

div.head: SCENE Brazen's houſe.
div.stage: Flaſh and Brazen at a gaming table.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: (riſing in a paſſion) Damnation ſeize me, if you did not pack the cards.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: It is a damn'd lie, ſir.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Dare you give a ſoldier the lie, ſir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Yes, I dare, when he tells one.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Come, old fellow, I don't mean to quarrel with you. (offers his hand.)

sp.speaker: Brazen,
sp.p: Pay the money you have loſt.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Don't be hard, old fellow; I've no money but the public's, not a ſhilling.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Public or private, pay, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Conſider, ſir, the ſervice muſt be injured, if I apply the public money to any purpoſes, but thoſe for which I received it.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Damn the ſervice: what's the ſervice to me? pay ſir.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: I'll give you my note on demand.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Your note! damn your note, I'll have the money.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Lord! how I tremble with rage, (ſees Pickle coming). A brother officer, by God! a reinforcement (aſide) my note, ſir, is as good as any man's note. Damn you, ſir, you have raiſed my blood. I demand ſatisfaction. (draws his ſword.)

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Lay down your ſtickfrog, and I'll give you ſatisfaction. (puts himſelf in the attitude of boxing.)

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: What! you are for fifty cuffs? Oh! no, no, honey, I am no black-guard. Come on, my dear. Here's the ſtuff, honey.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Your ſervant, my dear, (ſtands in the attitude of fencing.)

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: What! at points, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Draw, my dear, for the honour of the profeſſion, draw.—Sir, 'tis a diſgrace upon a ſoldier to have a fiſt cock'd in his company.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Your antagoniſt has no other weapon. Here's my ſword, ſir, (offering his ſword to Brazen.)

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you. Now, come on, you ſcoundrel.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: What! Aid the enemy! Hark'ye, my dear, your name! (to Pickle.)

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: That's captain Feather, of the flying camp. Come on, ſir, I ſay. (to Flaſh.)

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: I have nothing to ſay to you, ſir, (to Brazen.) Captain, I ſhould be glad to ſpeak with you. Walk out, if you pleaſe, ſir. (to Pickle.)

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: The ſword, if you pleaſe, (Brazen gives the ſword) Come, ſir, I'll attend you.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: But upon ſecond thoughts, my dear, I can ſay, what I have to ſay, here. You ſeem from the northward, from your uniform.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Perhaps not, ſir.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: You are a ſcoundrel. ſir, (to Flaſh.)

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Do you hear that, captain?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Waſhington has done wonders to the northward, ſir, (to Pickle.)

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: You are a damn'd coward, I ſay. (to Flaſh.)

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Are you from the northward, captain? (to Pickle.)

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: I am, ſir.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: In what corps? in the ſervice of what ſtate, ſir?

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: Damn your impertinence; what right have you to catechiſe any gentleman in my houſe? (kicks Flaſh out.)

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: I'll be reveng'd, damn'me, I'll make you pay for this, honey. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Can that fellow be an officer?

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: Yes; and, I once thought, a fellow of ſpirit. But he is too mean to talk about. I thought captain, you had taken your departure for the ſouthward, yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: It was my intention when I left this place, Sir. But hearing of Waſhington's freſh ſucceſs, I am now haſtening to the ſcene of action, hoping that I may partake of the glory acquired by our noble commander in the frequent rencountres with the enemy.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: Noble, captain! give me your hand. You are for the place of danger, I find.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Danger and honour are two aſſociates that go hand in hand. We muſt encounter the one to obtain the other. Honour is the idol I worſhip; to that I would ſacrifice my life and limbs.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: What can Britiſh mongrels do with ſuch men as theſe. Thirty thouſand of them will be but a breakfaſt for us.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Rather hard of digeſtion (aſide.) I ſhould be glad to pay my reſpects to the ladies, ſir, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: By all means. They are all from home except Mira. I'll ſend her to you. She'll be glad to ſee you, I'm ſure. Exit

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: I make no doubt of it. Now, hat under arm, a low bow, and a moſt obſequious face.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: So, Mr. Slyboots, are you here again?

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: At your ſervice, madam, and upo • an errand of a ſimilar nature to the laſt.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: You have a letter for me, then.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Yes, madam, upon my knees I preſent it; and in token of the great reſpect I have for the writer, I muſt kiſs the hand that receives it.

sp.speaker: Mira
sp.p: reads. "On Edgehill—at ſix in the evening —Meanwell and his truſty ſquire—your affectionate Trueman." You are the truſty ſquire, I ſuppoſe, and can inform me more fully, perhaps, of Mr. Trueman's intentions, than he has ventured to communicate in his letter.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Yes, madam, I can tell you Mr. Trueman's intentions, I believe.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Do, ſir.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: His intentions are to run away.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Run away!

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Yes, madam, with a beautiful angel like your ladyſhip, and to marry her as ſoon as he can get a perſon legally authoriſed to perform the ceremony.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: So the plot is out. Well, Trueman, love ſweetly ſupplicates for worth like thine; I ſurrender.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: What a charming creature! (aſide)

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Here, ſir, deliver this ring to Mr. Trueman; tell him, what he gave me as a token of his love, I now ſend as a token of my fidelity to him.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: What a pretty way theſe fine women have of winding themſelves round a man's heart! (aſide)

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Inform him, I will play the obedient miſtreſs that I may ſooner learn to act the dutiful wife.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, you ſay ſo many fine things I ſhall forget: Do write.

sp.speaker: Mira.
sp.p: Time will not permit, adieu. Exit.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: Well, captain, did Mira know you again?

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Perfectly, ſir. Miſs and I had ſome converſation yeſterday; ſhe recognized me at once.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: I did not obſerve you had a word to ſay to any body but my old woman.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: A little acquaintance gives the tongue a privilege with people of my profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: Soldiers are ſeldom at a loſs for talk, they ſay.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Very ſeldom. I'm at a damnable loſs tho' to contrive an excuſe for getting away decently. (aſide)

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: Come, captain, lay by your ſword. You'll ſtay with me to-night.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: Excuſe me, good ſir, when duty commands, the inclination muſt obey. I ſhould be happy to ſtay with you many days, but the honour of a ſoldier compels me to repair to the ſcene of action.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: The honour of a ſoldier! That's true: Well, noble captain, ſucceſs attend you

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: I thank you, ſir, for your civilities, and am your moſt obedient ſervant. Exit.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: A decent, well-bred lad, and a fellow of ſpirit, I warrant. Well, I'll go in purſuit of that cowardly ſcoundrel, and cudgel the raſcal, or make him pay me my money. Exit.

div.head: SCENE a Court-houſe.
div.stage: Enter Col. Simple and Mr. Tackabout.

sp.speaker: Simple.
sp.p: (with a newſpaper in his hand.) This is great news, glory to the Lord for it. The Lord is on our ſide, I am taught to believe, for we have great ſucceſs, Mr. Tackabout.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tack.
sp.p: Nothing but the tories can hurt us; nothing elſe, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Praiſe be to God they are vaſtly ſcattered.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: There are many in this county. I am ſurprized the committee don't handle the fellows. I am determined, unleſs ſomething is done with them, to head a mob myſelf, and burn down their houſes.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: With the Lord's will, ſomething ought to be done. Indeed, there ſhould.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: You, as preſident of the committee, ſhould cite the ſcoundrels. Let them be ſtigmatized; mark them out, and it's an eaſy matter to ſet a mob upon their backs that ſhall drive them to the devil.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why, ſir, we have had ſeveral before the committee, already, but it has pleaſed goodneſs that nothing could be made appear againſt them.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: You have tories in the committee, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: God forbid.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Two of the members dined with a Scotchmen the other day.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Dine with a Scotchman! that was dreadful.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Dreadful, ſir, why, they deſerve to be hang'd. I was told they were in a private room, ſhut up. The perſon who told me, ſays he, peeped thro' the key-hole, and ſaw them wink to each other, and then drink; that they would every now and then, break out into a horſe laugh. He heard them drink damnation to all ſcoundrels—very plain.

sp.speaker: Simple.
sp.p: That was meant for ſomebody, I reckon.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: It was intended for the committee, ſir.

sp.speaker: Simple.
sp.p: Well, ſir▪ the committee is to meet to-day, you know, at your requeſt. You'll inform them of all ſuch things, I hope.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: I'll do my duty, depend upon it.

div.stage: Enter Brazen, Strut, Thunderbolt, Squib and Skip.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: Not pay! I thought the captain was fluſh of money.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: He's a damn'd ſcoundrel.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Mighty well! very fine! excellent terms, indeed, if the guardians of their country are to be ab • ſed by every fellow!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What is the matter, my dear, ſir?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p:
You know I dare not accept or give a challenge: It's contrary to ordinance. My hands are
tied up you ſee; yet truly, I am to be kicked, cuffed, and trod upon. I'll be damn'd if I would not give a million that I durſt cut that fellows head off. (pointing to Brazen.)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Surely, my friends, you have not uſed the captain ill?

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Uſe a ſoldier ill! They are our dependance —our ſupport—our every thing.

sp.speaker: Squib.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and we ſhould keep them from all harm.

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: No ſoldier ought to be hurt.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I lodge my complaint with you. If ſoldiers are to be abuſed, d'ye ſee me, becauſe they dare not give a challenge, and by a man too, d—n my ſoul if ever I pull trigger again. (cries.)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Gentlemen, we really ought to ſit upon this matter. (They all huddle round a table.)

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: That is not a buſineſs that comes before the committee, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: The committee; ſir, begging your pardon, have a right to take up what buſineſs they pleaſe; and and to give any opinion.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: So I always thought.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: Except againſt one of their own body. They have no right to try one another. A lawyer told me it would be imperium ſub imperio.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why, as you ſay, my friend, I don't think that would be right, nor ſafe neither, indeed.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: As Mr. Brazen is a member, we have no buſineſs with any matter that touches him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No, no, by no means.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Well, gentlemen, as that is your opinion,
Mr. Brazen, do take a ſeat; I ſay, gentlemen, as that is your opinion, captain, we can't do any thing in it, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Mighty well! very fine! ſo I am to be abuſed, and to have no ſatisfaction. D—nation ſeize me if I don't.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: (riſing) What will you do?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, ſit ſtill, if you pleaſe, I'm done with you, ſir. But I'll be d—m'd if I don't— (Brazen goes towards him.) I ſwear the peace, gentlemen, I ſwear the peace.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: You are an infamous coward, ſir.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Very pretty! noble doings! If I fight, I am to be broke; if not, to be abuſed; eh!

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: Walk out, if you pleaſe. (turns him out.)

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I'll go, ſir, but d—mme if I don't— Exit.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul, Mr. Brazen, I am ſurprized at you.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: For what, ſir?

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: That gentleman is an officer in the ſervice of the country.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: Suppoſe he is.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Our leading men treat our officers and ſoldiers with the greateſt reſpect, ſir. Whatever they do or ſay, is overlooked for the good of the ſervice.— They would not have one of them offended for the world, ſir: they would not, you may depend upon it.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: He is a ſcoundrel; as ſuch I have treated him: if you have a mind—take up the quarrel.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p:
I take up the quarrel! D—n the fellow, I don't care a farthing about him. No, no, old friend,
here's my hand; I would not quarrel with you for a dozen ſuch fellows Well, Mr. Preſident, are the culprits cited, agreeable to the liſt I gave you?

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: This fellow has more ſmoke than fire in him, I find. (aſide)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I told the doorkeeper to ſummon them. Enter Stitch. Mr. Stitch, have you ſummond them men as I told you of?

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: I have ſummoned four; Mr. Trueman, Mr. Meanwell, the reverend Mr. Preachwell, and a Scotch pedlar, an't pleaſe your honour.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: What are they charg'd with?

sp.speaker: Simple.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Tackabout there, gave me a paper, with all their crimes ſet down in it, but (ſearching his pockets) I've loſt it, I believe, ſome how or other. Howſomever, I can remember as how that Mr. Meanwell and Mr. Trueman are to be tried for dining with a Scotchman, Mr. Preachwell for eating upon a faſt day, and the Scotch pedlar for drinking the king's health.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: Well, where are they?

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Mr. Meanwe • l, and Mr. Trueman, promiſed to come. The parſon ſnuff'd up his noſe as bad as if he ſmell'd a ſtink. I'm ſartin, ſays I, it's not me that has let a —, mentioning the thing itſelf, an't like your honour. The words were hardly out of my mouth, before ſpang he took me with his foot.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: The parſon ſtrike!

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Yes; look, your honour, juſt here an't pleaſe your honour. (ſhewing his b—k ſi—c.)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Praiſe be to God, our holy teachers deteſt fighting.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: I ſaid ſo, an't pleaſe your honour. You a parſon, ſays I! By jing, he ran at me as vigue-rous as a lion, with a monſtratious ſtick; but durn the heels, thinks I, that lets the body ſuffer; ſo off I ran.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Did he ſay nothing?

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: He call'd me a dirty fellow, an't like your honour.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: Where is the pedlar?

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: He got the wind of me, and has made his eſcape out of the precincts, I believe.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: You ſay, Trueman and Meanwell promiſed to attend?

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: Yes, an't pleaſe your honour.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: Suppoſe we adjourn, Mr. Preſident, for half an hour, 'till the tories come?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Agreed. (The committee rifes) Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE the Court-houſe yard.
div.stage: Enter Trueman and Meanwell, meeting Tackabout.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Let us ſecure our pockets Meanwell.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Fie! my dear Sir, that is too ſevere.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: The viper that gives a wound, then licks it with an envenomed tongue, is not more noxious, more offenſive, than the baſe reptile thou art.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: 'Pon honour, gentlemen, I have the greateſt veneration for you both.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: So talk'd the artful ſerpent, when with ſhew of zeal, and love, he ſeduced our firſt parents.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: It is at your inſtance, Mr. Tackabout, we are called here: What is our offence?

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: At my inſtance! you aſtoniſh me: at my inſtance! I ſcorn it.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: If your baſeneſs was not perfectly plebeian, Mr. Tackabout, the exteriors of the gentleman might perhaps keep you concealed, but—

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Nature is too true to her bias not to make Mr. Tackabout always appear the complete villain ſhe intended him for.

div.stage: Brazen, Thunderbolt and Simple croſſing the ſtage.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: Mr. Tackabout is giving the tories a little more of his political catechiſm, I expect.

sp.speaker: Thund.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Tackabout, no favour to tories: let's have no pleading off; bring them before the committee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Yes, yes, let's have them before us.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: I have nothing to ſay againſt the gentlemen. I have no charge againſt them.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why, dear me! did not you have them cited. Did not you give me a paper?

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: That's loſt, thank heaven. (aſide)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Did not you give me a paper with their names?

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: I give you a paper! I might give you a paper and their names might be wrote upon it, but not by me, I aſſure you. You ſhould never betray your informers, ſir. It will ſtop all your proceedings. It's a breach of faith and confidence that I little expected, ſir, (aſide to Simple.)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Oh! dear me! Mr. Stitch, Mr. Stitch.
Where's the paper I gave you with the names of the men you were to ſummon.

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your honour, happening to meet with Mr. Pettifogger, the attorney, I ſhewed it to him. He told me it was a precept, and that I muſt leave a copy of it at every place I went to, but being a poor hand at writing, thof I have pretty good larning too, I bethought me as how it would do as well to leave the thing itſelf, ſo I gave the paper to that gentleman. (pointing to Trueman)

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Blown, by heavens! (aſide)

sp.speaker: Stitch.
sp.p: The paper Mr. Tackabout gave me, I loſt.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Here is the paper he gave me, and in my houſe this was found. (aſide to Tackabout.) Do you know this hand-writing?

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Hide it, for God's ſake, my dear ſir. (aſide) Come this way, and let me talk with you: Gentlemen, I wiſh to have a little converſation with Mr. Trueman. Will you give me leave?

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: Ay, ay, try what you can do with him. (the committee retire)

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: Do, my dear ſir, be adviſed. You know I'm a tory; if theſe fellows find me out, I ſhall be tore to pieces.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: To this gentleman (pointing to Meanwell) and myſelf, you profeſs yourſelf a tory; with theſe people you have the merit of being a whig. It's high time, Mr. Tackabout, for you to be ſhewn in your proper colours; for, under your preſent diſguiſe, you are a nuiſance to all parties.

div.stage: Enter Thunderbolt, Squib, and Skip, liſtening.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: I am a tory, ſir, 'pon honour, ſir, I am.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Then you are the baſe villain I always found you to be.

stage.hi: Enter Simple, Brazen, Strut and Summons.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Tackabout, theſe gentlemen were cited at your requeſt. Let's have 'em before us.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: I have no charge againſt them, gentlemen. I have talk'd the matter over with them, and am proud to find they are innocent.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well, well, what a pity! is there nobody here that can make any thing appear againſt them? We ſhall be laugh'd at if they get off ſo; indeed we ſhall, my friends.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: You appear anxious, ſir, to have us arraign'd: By interrogating us, you may be furniſhed with anſwers reſpecting any thing you wiſh to be inform'd of.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: As that is the caſe, I ſhall come to the point at once. Are you tories, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Explain what you mean by the word tory, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Tory! why ſurely every body knows what a tory is—a tory is—pray, gentlemen, explain to him what a tory is.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: A tory, ſir, is any one who diſapproves of men and meaſures.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: All ſuſpected perſons are call'd tories.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: If ſuſpicion makes a tory, I may be one; if a diſapprobation of men and meaſures conſtitutes a tory, I am one; but if a real attachment to the true intereſts of my country ſtamps me her friend, then I deteſt the opprobrious epithet of tory, as much as I do the inflammatory diſtinction of whig.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: How is that? this gentleman is neither whig nor tory.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Neither, ſir!—Yes, neither. Whenever the conduct and principles of neither are juſtifiable, I am neither; as far as the conduct and principles of either correſpond with the duties of a good citizen, I am both.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well, really, I don't underſtand him. Do any of you, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: I underſtand as how he ſays he is a tory, or no tory, a whig or no whig, juſt as the maggot bites.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: Why, mayhap, at this preſent time of aſking, he may be a whig, as we pretend to be. By and by he may be a tory, as occaſion offers.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: I deteſt the mean ſubterfuge: this low cunning I leave to your ſycophant, Mr. Tackabout.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Mr. Tackabout is no tory, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Aſk him, ſir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well, for the joke's ſake. Mr. Tackabout, the tories have a mind to turn the tables upon you. They ſeem to ſignify as how you are a tory.

sp.speaker: Tack.
sp.p: You are better acquainted with me, ſir, than to ſuſpect any thing of that, I hope.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why, to be ſure I am.

sp.speaker: Thun.
sp.p: Mr. Tackabout and the tories ſeemed very thick, a little while ago, while he was talking.

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: Let me tell, Mr. Thunderbolt.—While he was talking with the tories juſt now, Mr. Squib, and I bethought us of liſtening a bit.

sp.speaker: Squib.
sp.p: Yes, and he purteſted it was not owing to him theſe gentlemen were ſummoned. He ſignified he was a tory himſelf.

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: So he did.

sp.speaker: Squib.
sp.p: Fair play, is fair play, that gentleman call'd him a villain for it. (pointing to Trueman.)

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: The truth is the truth. That gentleman is leſſer a tory than Mr. Tackabout.

sp.speaker: Squib.
sp.p: So he is.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: (to Trueman) Give me your hand, you are an honeſt fellow: every tory is a villain. Henceforth, all malice apart.

sp.speaker: Thund.
sp.p: It ſeems as how the gentlemen are whigs and Mr. Tackabout the tory.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: They are honeſt fellows, I find. There's my hand (to Meanwell) gentlemen, I move that they be diſcharged.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What muſt be done to Mr. Tackabout?

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.p: Duck him.

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: Tar and feather him.

sp.speaker: Thund.
sp.p: Advertiſe him.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: He ſhould be duck'd, as an incendiary, tarr'd as a nuiſance, feather'd as a foul traitor, hang'd—

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: And advertis'd as a coward. (kicks him.) I beg pardon, gentlemen, but Mr. Tackabout's errors are ſo fundamental, that I can't help applying a certain ſpecific. (kicks him out.)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well, really, he is rightly ſerv'd.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Very right.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: Let us adjourn, and drive the fellow out of the yard.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed. Exeunt all but Trueman and Brazen.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: (taking Trueman by the hand.) You are an honeſt fellow, a fellow of ſpirit.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: I once eſteemed you as a friend, reſpected you as a father, Mr. Brazen.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: Well, well, all malice apart, it ſhall be ſo.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: What, good ſir?

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: You ſhall have her to-night, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: I am at a loſs for words.

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: Poh! poh! keep your words to yourſelf; you are welcome to her, that's enough; as I find you are no tory, that's enough; I ſay. Come, let's mob that raſcal of a fellow. Exit.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: So in ſpite of all the malice and cenſure of the times, I am at laſt dubb'd a whig. I am not wiſer or better than before. My political opinions are ſtill the ſame, my patriotic principles unaltered: but I have kick'd a tory, it ſeems: there is a merit it this, which, like charity, hides a multitude of ſins. Well, Mira, I have once more obtained your father's conſent to our union, and leſt ſome ſuſpicion or other ſhould again tickle his brain with the patriotic itch, I am determin'd to be thine this night.
sp.stage: Enter Pickle, not obſerving Trueman; ſings:
sp.l: The flocks, the herds, the pretty birds
Nature alone, obey;
Like them I'll range, like them I'll change,
As free, as bleſt as they.
sp.p: What he gave as a token of love, I now ſend as a token of my fidelity to him. So much for my leſſon. (looking at the ring) Alack! alack! how many poor creature • do theſe little magic circles make miſerable!

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: What ſine ſoliloquy are you meditating, moſt noble captain?

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Taken up with your buſineſs altogether, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: It becomes intricate, I fear, if it puzzles a man of your adroitneſs.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: I was ſtudying how to convey to you, in the beſt manner, the ſweeteſt meſſage that ever came from a fond miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: A lady's meſſage can loſe nothing of it's merit, when conveyed by ſo great an adept as you, ſir, but I expected a letter—

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: A letter! Lord, ſir, never aſk a letter from your miſtreſs. 'Tis the worſt way of procuring a tender of the affections in the world. A woman, when ſhe commits her ſentiments to paper, is ſo very cautious, ſo nicely circumſpect, leſt the warmth that animates the expreſſions of love, ſhould carry her beyond the uſual prudence of her ſex, that the glowing ardor of the paſſions, gives way to a cold prudiſh reſerve, which I call the grave of love; tho' ſome are pleaſed to call it the nurſery of virtue. How • ver, ſir, your miſtreſs aſſents to all your propoſals, and here are my credentials. (preſents the ring.)

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: I know the token too well, to doubt the faith of my dear girl, or the fidelity with which you have tranſacted the buſineſs entruſted to you. Take this as a ſmall acknowledgment. (offers a purſe.)

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: I never receive wages for conducting a love-intrigue. Theſe little offices of friendſhip circulate the affections ſo ſweetly, that I always find a reward in my own feelings without any adventitious one.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: The youngſter's expreſſions and ſentiments favour little of the footman, methinks. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Have you any farther commands, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Well, Trueman, you have got your pleni-potentiary with you, I find. The preliminaries are all ſettled, I ſuppoſe; and you have nothing to do but enter the fortreſs.

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: I have always had a friend in the citadel, the little traitor, love: but I have obtained by treaty, what I lately thought was only to be atchieved by ſtratagem.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: What? is the old governor in your intereſt again?

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: Yes, he aſſents to the ſurrender, and the terms of capitulation are all my own.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I congratulate you with all my ſoul: when is to be the happy day?

sp.speaker: True.
sp.p: This. I am determined to take the old fellow while he's in the humour. At ſix in the evening, I expect our plighted troth will be mutually exchanged. Even that happy hour will have a ſhade upon it unleſs diſpelled by your preſence: the old gentleman has been rude to you: can you forgive it?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: The intereſt you have in his affection leaves no room for my reſentment. You may expect me: 'till then, adieu.

stage.hi: Exeunt Meanwell and Tr • man ſeverally.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Well, ſince this affair of Mr. Trueman's is to be ſettled in the old hum drum ſtyle: I have nothing to do but to bring my amour to as ſpeedy a concluſion as poſſible. You to your Mira, Trueman, and I to my dear Melinda. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Poor Flaſh! to be broke if you fight, to be kick'd if you don't! (pull's off his coat.) Lie there, commiſſion and cowardice, together. (draws his ſword) now, d—me, come on, ha, hah! (puſhing at the ground) how I could fight, if I durſt.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Well, ma'am, I have taken a commiſſion, purely to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Your courage muſt be tried, indeed it muſt, colonel, before I can conſent. Stop, (ſeeing Flaſh.) A man fighting his own ſhadow. See, my dear colonel; now is the time to attack him: do fight him colonel; I long of all things in the world, to ſee a duel.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Hah! there I had him. Hah! again, by God! through and through d—me! (Iſabella puſhes Strut up to him.) Mercy on me! (ſtarts back and drops his ſword.)

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Speak to him, colonel.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: (putting his foot on the ſword.) Who are you, ſir?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: But ſtay, colonel, let the man have his ſword. (takes up the ſword and gives it to Flaſh.)

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: May I take the liberty to enquire your name, ſir?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: My name! d—me, ſir, what right have you to my name?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: He curſes you, colonel; pick a quarrel with him; do, dear colonel.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: What! quarrel with a madman? The man is deranged in his mind. Are you not frantic, ſir?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Frantic, my name Frantic! D—mn you, ſir, I'll not be nick-named by any ſcoundrel living.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Scoundrel! now we ſhall have it, draw, colonel. (She takes Strut's hand, and puts it upon the hilt of his ſword.)

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: He did not call me ſcoundrel, madam. He only ſaid he would not be nick-named by any ſcoundrel living. I have not nick-named him, madam.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: It is a lie, ſir.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: What ſay you to that, colonel?

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: The man is mad, abſolutely mad, madam.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Blood and fire.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: (Draws Struts ſword and puts it in his hand.) Now, colonel.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: A pretty blade, let's ſee it my dear.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Let him feel it, colonel. Up to him. (puſhes up Strut.)

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: (puts up his own ſword, and advances to look at that of Strut.) With your leave, my dear, from France, no doubt. I have heard they are all the beſt poliſhers in the world.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Stand off, ſir; what did you mean by calling me a ſcoundrel?

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: I call you a ſcoundrel! Upon my ſoul, my dear, you are diſordered in your mind.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: This lady ſays you did, ſir.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: D—mn all ladies, ſay I; they are always making miſchief, by ſetting honeſt fellows by the ears.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: I told you, madam, he did not call me a ſcoundrel.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: I heard him give you the lie in plain terms.

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: Don't believe her, my dear. You and I won't quarrel about what a woman ſays: they will tell fibbs, d—n'd fibbs, ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: You hear, madam; he did not give me the lie.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a paltry coward! to put up with ſuch an affront, and then ſtand parleying with a fellow who only apologizes for it, by abuſing his miſtreſs? give me the ſword. (Takes the ſword and runs at Flaſh.)

sp.speaker: Flaſh.
sp.p: A man in petticoats, by God! oh, ho! my dear, I ſmell a rat. Yes, yes, honey, catch Flaſh if you can. Two to one! Oh! no, no, my dear; I'll not be aſſaſſinated by God. (runs off.)

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: That laſt reproach of your's, my dear madam, raiſed my blood to ſuch a pitch—if he had not gone off—D—n the fellow, I muſt have kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Colonel Strut, your moſt obedient. Henceforth, I diſclaim all connexions with you. Never dare to ſpeak to me, nor hope ever hereafter, to ſee my face again. This I will take as the trophy of my victory. Exit with Flaſh's coat.

sp.speaker: Strut.
sp.p: Well, I don't know whether I am not better without her. She has ſuch a curſed ſtomach for fighting, ſhe would certainly have brought me into ſome ſcrape or other, in ſpite of my teeth.

lg.l: Honour's a bubble, fame a ſound
Not worth a man's purſuing;
Women at beſt, are evil's ſound,
And oft bring men to ruin.

div.head: SCENE Meanwell's houſe.

sp.speaker: Pickle.
sp.p: My maſter's ſervants are a ſet of honeſt fellows. The butler made a few ſcruples at firſt, but upon his trying on the canonical habit, and my telling him he would make a charming methodiſt preacher, by God, the old fellow kick'd conſcience out of doors, and immediately became a new creature— Enter the butler, in a clergyman's gown. Sage father, your moſt humble. A little more gravity, and you'll top the hypocrite ſo perfectly, that tho' true ſanctity may bluſh at thee, yet iniquity will own thee her's for ever.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I don't much like the buſineſs you have ſet me upon, Mr. Pickle.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Poh! you ſhall have a buſs of the bride, a reward that would make lechery kick up the beam, tho' weigh'd againſt the charity of a biſhop. Beſides, as my tenure will be of ſhort duration, I expect you may like her in reverſion; a gratuity that a lecher of the Romiſh church would lick his chops at, with avidity.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: It goes againſt my conſcience, Mr. Pickle.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Conſcience! ha, ha, ha, as long as you are in that habit, you may defy the devil, and all his imps. Conſcience only ſerves as a bugbear to the laity, the clergy are above it's trifling fears. For ſhame, don't diſgrace the cloth, old fellow.—Go take the cook and ſcullion with you. You know our maſter is to be at Mr. Trueman's wedding to-night, we ſhall not be miſs'd.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: It is a ſin to deceive a poor innocent girl, Mr. Pickle.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Poh! poh! curſe your canting, come along.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: All the ſin muſt lie upon your head.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Well, I don't care, ſo I have the pleaſure ſomewhere elſe.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: You muſt bear me harmleſs.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Well, I muſt go then, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Pick.
sp.p: Come on. Exit with the butler.

div.stage: Enter Meanwell, with a letter in his hand.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: My old friend, Mr. Worthy, writes me that his nephew, George, had arrived from England, about the beginning of our public diſturbances; that being too free in diſcovering his political opinions, he was cited before one of their courts. To avoid the treatment he expected to receive from theſe guardians of the rights and liberties of their fellow-citizens, he abſconded without informing his friends of his route or deſigns. I am requeſted to make enquiry after him. We have no aſylum with us to which perſecuted integrity would fly for ſhelter. No, no, he is not with us.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: Mr. Trueman preſents his compliments to your honour: ſays he is gone off to Mr. Brazen's, and deſires you will follow him as ſoon as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p:
(looking at his watch.) Six is the hour. Tell your maſter, I'll be with him at the time appointed. Exit Groom. My butler juſt informed me that an old tenant of mine, formerly one of my beſt and moſt faithful domeſtics,
has ſent to me very preſſingly to call on him in my way to the wedding. He has urgent buſineſs with me. I muſt comply with his requeſt, and not to be too late, I'll prepare immediately for my journey. Who's there? Enter a ſervant. Where's Tickle?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your honour, I don't know. But ſince he turned captain, I ſuppoſe as how he's after ſome of his wild vagaries. I ſaw him go out not long ago, with ſomebody wrap'd up in a gown.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: You did! Farther enquiry ſhould be made into this. Do you think any of the ſervants can tell whither he is gone?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: They ſay it is a profound ſecret, but I thinks your honour, it can't be after any good.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Don't be too ſuſpicious of a fellow-ſervant, but which of them told you it was a ſecret?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: The cook, your honour: ſays he to me, Mr. Pickle is a fly cock, ſays he, and knows what to do, ſays he, but I hope your honour won't tell as how I told you.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Get ye gone, and tell the cook to come hither. (Exit ſervant.) That young man is out of the way at a very improper time, and may probably have ſome trick in view. He appears to be a faithful and honeſt, and at the ſame time the moſt ingenious and genteel ſervant, I ever ſaw; but nevertheleſs, it is not impoſſible but he may have a mixture of the rake in his diſpoſition. Let me ſee, what girl is there hereabouts whom he can have in view? It is not my wiſh to pry into all the actions of my ſervants, but no improper conduct muſt be permitted.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Well, ſir, can you give me any account of Mr Pickle?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Your honour won't be offended, I hope. I don't wiſh to raiſe miſchief againſt a brother ſervant.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: You know my authority when I chooſe to exert it on a proper occaſion, muſt not be diſputed. I underſtand that Pickle has gone out with ſome perſon muffled up in a cloke, and as ſecrecy is generally the veil of iniquity, I am confident he has ſome evil deſign. If you know any thing of his ſchemes, I inſiſt upon your faithfully diſcloſing them to me.

sp.speaker: Cook.
